content.question: What is the purpose of redundancy in aircraft design?

options.A: Save weight by getting rid of unnecessary structure.
options.B: Save costs by getting rid of unnecessary structure.
options.C: Providing an alternative load path or source in case the prime load path or source fails.
options.D: Save weight by getting rid of unnecessary components.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.01.01.01.02: Explain the purpose of redundancy in aircraft design. Redundancy is another word for additional, or duplicate, and means that there is not just one load path or one source for any system. Essentially, to provide the correct amount of safety in the case of a failure under the "fail-safe" design concept, there needs to be another option to stop a catastrophic event occurring. For structural items, this is usually multiple load paths, so that if one breaks, the other can take the required forces without fully breaking. For systems, there are usually extra sources (electrical power, hydraulic pressure, etc.) to stop a complete failure of the more essential systems, such as flight controls or landing gear extension.

options.B: It should be 150% of the “ultimate load".

options.D: It should be 150% of what the aircraft is expected to experience in flight.

key_points: Note: This should be a principles of flight question really, as per the learning objectives, but it has been reported mutiple times in AGK
The limit load (usually known as limit load factor) of an aeroplane is the maximum load it is expected to experience during flight operations
The aircraft must be capable of withstanding 150% of this "limit load" before failure occurs (which is the "ultimate load")
learning.explanation: Note: This should be a principles of flight question really, as per the learning objectives, but it has been reported mutiple times in AGK. The limit load (usually known as limit load factor) of an aeroplane is the maximum load it is expected to experience during flight operations. The aircraft must be capable of withstanding 150% of this "limit load" before failure occurs (which is the "ultimate load"). CS-25 aircraft, for instance, have a limit load factor of 2.5G at the minimum, meaning that they must be tested to 3.75G (150% of 2.5) without failure. Any forces higher than 2.5G can begin to cause irreversible bending of the airframe and are not assured to be withstood by every airframe in a fleet, so it is never recommended to exceed this limit load factor unless extreme circumstances make it necessary for safety.

content.question: Which of the following fluids carried on board an aircraft may all be considered corrosive?

options.A: Battery acid, fuel & mercury.
options.B: Toilet waste, fuel & hydraulic fluid.
options.C: Battery acid, drinking water & toilet waste.
options.D: Hydraulic fluid, fuel & water.

key_points: Corrosion is where two substances begin to change the composition of each other when mixed
Sometimes this is by literally breaking down the composition of the other substance, which is the most dramatic form of corrosion
This happens when one of the substances is corrosive to the other one
learning.explanation: Corrosion is where two substances begin to change the composition of each other when mixed. Sometimes this is by literally breaking down the composition of the other substance, which is the most dramatic form of corrosion. This happens when one of the substances is corrosive to the other one. For instance, Mercury is HIGHLY corrosive to aluminium, and burns straight through aluminium if the two come into contact (also producing toxic fumes; they really are not a very pleasant combination). To address the options in this question: Mercury is corrosive (to aluminium and a few other metals particularly) as stated earlier. Battery Acid is corrosive also. It is quite easy to remember this one, for obvious reasons. Fuel is not corrosive, which is very useful for storage (but it can allow the breeding of bacteria that can be corrosive to metal fuel tanks). Hydraulic Fluid is annoyingly complex when it comes to corrosiveness. One of the favourable properties of a good hydraulic fluid is for it to be non-corrosive. This is the case when it is in contact with metal, but it can be corrosive to paintwork, certain types of rubber seals, etc. Water is corrosive due to oxidisation, which causes rust. It is not highly corrosive, but the air contained within water will slowly break down materials like unprotected metals. Toilet Waste is a mixture of water (corrosive) and ammonia, as well as bacteria, all of which are corrosive to various materials

options.B: Cyclic loads are present when loading cargo aircraft with mailboxes.
options.C: They are caused by the loads generated by the engines.

key_points: Cyclic loading is the application of repeated or fluctuating stresses, strains, or stress intensities to locations on structural components

For instance, a cyclic load may be on the fuselage on each landing as a result of the impact on touchdown or the force of pressurisation on the fuselage and bulkheads, which increases and decreases regularly per flight
The degradation that may occur at the location is referred to as fatigue degradation or failure
learning.explanation: Cyclic loading is the application of repeated or fluctuating stresses, strains, or stress intensities to locations on structural components. For instance, a cyclic load may be on the fuselage on each landing as a result of the impact on touchdown or the force of pressurisation on the fuselage and bulkheads, which increases and decreases regularly per flight. The degradation that may occur at the location is referred to as fatigue degradation or failure. Many of an aircraft's cyclic loads have to be kept track of, to ensure the correct maintenance takes place on the components involved, as degradation is high with these repetitive loads in the same locations. "Pilots need to log every landing in order to know when cyclic load limitations may be exceeded." Correct. By keeping a record of landings, pilots and maintenance personnel can ensure that the aircraft remains within safe operating limits. Exceeding cyclic load limitations can lead to structural fatigue or damage, compromising the safety and airworthiness of the aircraft.

What is correct for fail safe designed structural components?
1. There is more than one load carrying component
2. One load carrying component is sufficient, provided it is strong enough
3. The component is removed at the end of the calculated life time or number of cycles
4. The design is based on the principle of redundancy of components

options.A: 1 and 3.
options.B: 1 and 4.
options.C: 2 and 3.
options.D: 2 and 4.

key_points: Structural design concepts are developed to ensure safe operation of aircraft components
The Safe-life philosophy indicates that a component in the aircraft has a given time period or life cycle that it should withstand without any failure
The life of such a structure can be defined in different ways, cycles, flight hours, pressurization events or calendar time
learning.explanation: Structural design concepts are developed to ensure safe operation of aircraft components. The Safe-life philosophy indicates that a component in the aircraft has a given time period or life cycle that it should withstand without any failure. The life of such a structure can be defined in different ways, cycles, flight hours, pressurization events or calendar time. The Safe-life philosophy requires parts to be replaced at the end of their specified life, regardless of their condition. A Fail-safe structural element is designed so that the part distributes the load in a way that it goes through multiple load paths. This means that in the case of a crack in the structural element appearing, the rest of the structure is still able to withstand the prescribed loads for a limited amount of time until the crack is detected by maintenance and the element replaced. This principle is called redundancy.

content.question: Reading the technical log of an aircraft before flight, you notice that the previous maintenance organisation inspected the landing gear for corrosion, and made no further action as no corrosion was found. What type of maintenance is this?

options.A: Hard-time maintenance, where an item is completely removed and disassembled to allow for a thorough inspection of the item.
options.B: On-condition maintenance, where an aircraft item such as the landing gear is removed from service at or before reaching a specified time or amount of cycles.
options.C: Hard-time maintenance, overhauling an aircraft component within the time limits of the maintenance programme as determined by the manufacturer.
options.D: On-condition maintenance, where the determination of continued airworthiness can be made without overhaul or tear-down inspection.

key_points: There are two main types of maintenance process: Hard-time maintenance: refers to planned maintenance of a component, which is overhauled or replaced upon a set number of flight hours or cycles of operation
It is strictly forbidden to allow components to remain in service after the conclusion of their hard-time period
On-condition maintenance: refers to predictive maintenance that involves replacement or overhaul of components before a failure happens
learning.explanation: There are two main types of maintenance process: Hard-time maintenance: refers to planned maintenance of a component, which is overhauled or replaced upon a set number of flight hours or cycles of operation. It is strictly forbidden to allow components to remain in service after the conclusion of their hard-time period. On-condition maintenance: refers to predictive maintenance that involves replacement or overhaul of components before a failure happens. Regular inspection of components gives maintenance teams records about the condition of each monitored part on an aircraft. This type of maintenance is based on monitoring of critical parameters of a component or piece of equipment and its replacement if a limit value is exceeded. The inspections are often done without completely tearing down each component, as indicators of wear or damage can be seen quickly, without excess work or aircraft down-time.

content.question: Which of the following indications might you see during a pre-flight inspection that suggests continuous stress on the airframe?

options.B: Paint wear and bulges.
options.C: Impact dents or scratches
options.D: Faded paintwork

key_points: Visible cracking is an indication of continuous stress on the airframe because it suggests that the material of the airframe is experiencing strain that is exceeding its yield strength
Buckling is similar, but that indicates that significant compression has occurred, also a form of stress
This could be caused by a variety of factors, such as turbulence, excessive vibration, or high loads during takeoff or landing
learning.explanation: Visible cracking is an indication of continuous stress on the airframe because it suggests that the material of the airframe is experiencing strain that is exceeding its yield strength. Buckling is similar, but that indicates that significant compression has occurred, also a form of stress. This could be caused by a variety of factors, such as turbulence, excessive vibration, or high loads during takeoff or landing. Over time, the stress can cause the material to weaken, which can lead to catastrophic failure if not addressed. The above image was apparently the result of a hard landing, which makes sense as it is around the main gear. Paint wear and bulges, impact dents and scratches, and faded paintwork may all be cosmetic issues that do not necessarily indicate stress on the airframe. While impact dents may cause localized stress, they do not necessarily indicate continuous stress on the entire airframe. It is important to regularly inspect the aircraft for signs of stress and take appropriate maintenance and repair actions to ensure safe and reliable operation.

On-condition maintenance: refers to predictive maintenance that involves replacement or overhaul of components before a failure happens. Regular inspection of components gives maintenance teams records about the condition of each monitored part on an aircraft. This type of maintenance is based on monitoring of critical parameters of a component or piece of equipment and its replacement if a limit value is exceeded. The inspections are often done without completely tearing down each component, as indicators of wear or damage can be seen quickly, without excess work or aircraft down-time. The two maintenance processes are more or less useful for different components of an aircraft, dependent on their wear, risk of failure, etc. This means that an aircraft will often have hard-time maintenance tasks on some components, and on-condition maintenance tasks on other components. If the aircraft has a CRS (Certificate of Release to Service), it has been checked and is considered airworthy until a defect is found or the time/cycle limits given are reached.

content.question: Which of the following areas of the aircraft are prone to stress, and should the pilot pay close attention to during the pre-flight inspection?

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.01.02.01.03: Describe the areas typically prone to stress that should be given particular attention during a pre-flight inspection, and highlight the limited visual cues of any deformation that may be evident. This question and the available options are quite ridiculous. We believe that the wing root fairings are probably most correct, as they cover the wing root, the highest stress point on the aircraft, and any deformation (due to high stress) would cause cracking, which may be visible on the fairing. However, it appears that most authorities are considering the "wing root fairings" to be incorrect (Spain and Poland confirmed). We think the next best answer is the "aft pressure bulkhead", but that is unconfirmed. Please send us any further exam feedback you have and let us know which authority you sat with, thank you! We obviously agree that a thorough inspection of the tail skid is important, as this is where evidence of tailstrikes would show, but we find the wording a little incongruous. We cannot inspect the aft pressure bulkhead itself - which is the area prone to stress due to pressurisation - as it is inside the aircraft skin, and the tail-skid itself is not naturally prone to stress (other than damage from tailstrikes). Furthermore, if the aft pressure bulkhead is considered correct, surely the forward pressure bulkhead must be correct also, in the fact that it cannot be inspected directly (as it is internal), but the outer skin can be inspected and is also prone to damage (birdstrikes). Therefore, we find it very unclear what the examiner is really asking here. Realistically, the exam wording makes quite a big difference to the question also. If the question does not include "prone to stress", then the argument is very different, as well as if different options are present. Neither the question nor the options have been verified as having the exact wording. We therefore need as much feedback for this one as we can get, thank you! NOTE: The answer with the UK CAA is not yet confirmed.

content.question: Windshield heating of a transport aeroplane is…

options.A: used to clear rain.
options.B: only used when hot-air demisting is insufficient.
options.C: essential to improve the strength and flexibility of the cockpit windows.
options.D: not required below FL360.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.02.04.01.10: Explain the function of window heating for structural purposes. The flight deck windshield is made of many different layers of materials, mostly plastics such as acrylic and vinyl, as well as some layers of toughened glass, to give it favourable properties such as high strength, good flexibility (for impact resistance) and a hard wearing outer coating, with good rain resistance. They also contain heating elements which have a couple of different jobs, their main job being to keep the plastics in a slightly softer state, where they are flexible enough to absorb and deflect impacts from objects like birds at very high speeds. If the heating was not present, then the windshield would become very brittle in the extreme cold of the upper airways and could break more easily upon impact. The secondary jobs of the heated windshield are de-fogging and de-icing, which are important in their own right, but are certainly a secondary consideration to the impact resistance.

To achieve this, flight deck windows are constructed from several layers. A heating element is added to the tough outer glass. There are two main benefits of heating: The first is icing resistance due to the increased temperature of the surface. Windshield heat controllers are generally capable of handling two primary functions: de-fog and de-ice. Cockpit side windows often do not feature window heating but are only equipped with defogging devices. The second is that the heated glass stays in a temperature range where it is less rigid. Window heating ensures the screen vinyl layer is kept elastic and resilient and better to absorb damage in case of a bird strike/hail. For this reason most, if not all, commercial aircraft with heated windshields will have a speed restriction below 10 000 ft if the windshield heat is inoperative, commonly not above 250 KIAS below 10 000 ft.

content.question: Which of the following can help to reduce the vertical bending moments experienced by an aircraft wing during flight?

options.A: Filling the tanks with fuel.
options.B: Increasing the number of passenger seats.
options.C: Reducing the size of the vertical stabiliser.
options.D: Increasing the size of the windows around the wings.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.02.03.03.04: Explain the following countermeasures used to achieve stress relief and reduce resonance: chord-wise and span-wise position of masses (e.g. engines, fuel, balance masses for wing and control balance masses); torsional stiffness; bending flexibility; fuel-balancing procedures during flight (automatic or applied by the pilot). When an aircraft is in flight, the weight of the whole aircraft is being suspended by the wings. This means that the forces on the wings are enormous, and the wing roots in particular take a massive strain. These forces result in the wings flexing upwards during flight, as the outer sections of the wings are exerting force all through the wing spar, which causes it to bend slightly upwards. We do not want extremely stiff wings, as they would be brittle, and more likely to break. We are therefore happy for wings to flex, and it has become more common in newer aircraft to allow a lot of flex. Of course, there is only so much flex a material can handle though, so we can counteract it by changing an aircraft's design and how we operate it. By putting fuel in the wings, we weigh them down, to fight off some of the upwards flex from the lift. Most aircraft have their wings as their main tanks, so there is always some fuel in the wings to make this happen. This is also one of the reasons that many aircraft use up the fuel in their centre (fuselage) tanks first when possible, leaving the wing tanks full until the aircraft is a little lighter, and has less wing flex.

learning.explanation: MATERIALS Modern aircraft are constructed mainly of aluminium and its alloys with smaller amounts of steel and titanium for the major structural components with composite materials used extensively for more lightly loaded structures. However many of the latest aircraft make use of modern composites for the empennage, cabin floor panels, flying control surfaces, engine cowlings and fairings. Each material is chosen for its particular properties with regard to fatigue strength, wear resistance, strength to weight ratio, fire resistance etc. COMPOSITE MATERIALS Composite materials are made of at least two elements to produce a material with properties that are different to those of the original elements. Nearly all composites consist of a bulk material, this is called the matrix and some form of reinforcement. This reinforcement is used mainly to increase the strength and stiffness of the matrix and is usually in a fibre form. ADVANTAGES OF COMPOSITE MATERIALS - The ability to arrange the fibres to obtain directional properties consistent with the load - The ability to make complex shapes, since the material is not homogeneous - Weight savings - Resistance to corrosion - High specific strength - High specific stiffness DISADVANTAGES OF COMPOSITE MATERIALS - They are quickly eroded by hail, sand, etc, so leading edges must be sheathed. - They are difficult to repair. - They can absorb moisture if the material is not correctly sealed. When comparing composite and metal structures, composite are: - Lighter: Composites can be up to 70 percent lighter than metal. - High strength-to-weight ratio: composites have a high strength-to-weight ratio. Carbon fiber weighs about 25% as much as steel and 70% as much as aluminum, and is much stronger and stiffer than both materials per weight. Therefore, statement II is incorrect. - Stronger: When increasing the strength of metal, it must be equally strong in all directions thickening the material and causing an increase in weight. Composites however can be engineered and designed to be strong in a specific direction while keeping it lightweight. Therefore, statement I is incorrect. - Corrosion Resistant: Composites resist weather damage and other harsh chemicals that would typically damage metal. - Nonconductive: Unlike steel, composites are nonconductive.

content.question: How can upwards wing flex be avoided?

options.A: Move C of G forwards.
options.B: Increase take off weight.
options.C: Place the engines closer to the fuselage.
options.D: Keep fuel in the wing tanks as long as possible.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.02.03.03.04: Explain the following countermeasures used to achieve stress relief and reduce resonance: chord-wise and span-wise position of masses (e.g. engines, fuel, balance masses for wing and control balance masses); torsional stiffness; bending flexibility; fuel-balancing procedures during flight (automatic or applied by the pilot). When an aircraft is in flight, the weight of the whole aircraft is being suspended by the wings. This means that the forces on the wings are enormous, and the wing roots in particular take a massive strain. These forces result in the wings flexing upwards during flight, as the outer sections of the wings are exerting force all through the wing spar, which causes it to bend slightly upwards. We do not want extremely stiff wings, as they would be brittle, and more likely to break. We are therefore happy for wings to flex, and it has become more common in newer aircraft to allow a lot of flex. Of course, there is only so much flex a material can handle though, so we can counteract it by changing an aircraft's design and how we operate it. By putting fuel in the wings, we weigh them down, to fight off some of the upwards flex from the lift. Most aircraft have their wings as their main tanks, so there is always some fuel in the wings to make this happen. This is also one of the reasons that many aircraft use up the fuel in their centre (fuselage) tanks first when possible, leaving the wing tanks full until the aircraft is a little lighter, and has less wing flex.

content.question: Which of the following statements correctly details the reasons and implications for some aircraft designs mounting the horizontal stabiliser on top of the fin (T-tail)?

options.A: It increases manoeuvrability and responsiveness, it is a simpler design and therefore saves on production cost, but it is harder to inspect after de-icing, and requires more ground handling equipment.
options.B: It has a smoother airflow and therefore more predictable flight characteristics, but requires a stronger, heavier fin, and is susceptible to loss of effectiveness at high angles of attack.
options.C: It allows for greater ground clearance when taxiing, it is a simpler design, therefore saving production cost, but it is harder to inspect after de-icing, and requires more ground handling equipment.
options.D: It has a smoother airflow, therefore more predictable flight characteristics, it has a wider operating range in pitch, but requires a stronger, therefore heavier fin.

key_points: Note: this does delve into priciples of flight a little, but is still within AGK enough to be acceptable
Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Note: this does delve into priciples of flight a little, but is still within AGK enough to be acceptable. Learning Objective 021.02.03.01.01: Describe the following types of design and explain their advantages and disadvantages: high-mounted wing; low-mounted wing; low- or mid-set tailplane; T-tail. There are two main places that an aircraft designer can mount a horizontal stabiliser at the rear of an aircraft. One place is "low mounted", at the base of the tail fin, and the other place is at the top of the fin, a "T-tail" due to its shape looking like the letter "T". The low-mounted position tends to be more common on large civilian transport aircraft these days, but both mounting locations have their own positive and negative factors. We will now talk about T-tail in comparison to low-mounted. T-tails have the horizontal stabiliser up and away from the turbulence created by the wing (during normal flight), which means the airflow over the tailplane is smoother. As the tailplane is therefore less affected by the downwash from the main wing, we can refer to this mounting position as "stabilising" (some questions in PoF ask about this). T-tails also make the fin and rudder more effective, as they act as a winglet for the fin and rudder, so a smaller rudder is required. However, all the forces produced by the horizontal stabiliser and the elevators must travel through the fin, meaning that the fin must be made much stronger (and therefore heavier) than if the stabiliser was mounted on the fuselage at the bottom. Also, a more practical consideration is that inspection is more difficult, especially when it comes to icing/de-icing. The final consideration for a T-tail is probably the most well known. The horizontal stabiliser may be out of the way of the turbulence from the wing during normal flight, but at high angles of attack, the tailplane will now be within the stalled region behind the wing, leading to a stall where no elevator control is possible, called a deep-stall. Deep-stalls can sometimes be unrecoverable. So let's go through the options. "It increases manoeuvrability and responsiveness, it is a simpler design and therefore saves on production cost, but it is harder to inspect after de-icing, and requires more ground handling equipment." Incorrect. It has a stabilising effect on the aircraft, so decreases manoeuvrability. It is not simpler to design, requiring a very strong fin. It is obviously harder to inspect though, that bit is correct. "It has a smoother airflow and therefore more predictable flight characteristics, but requires a stronger, heavier fin, and is susceptible to loss of effectiveness at high angles of attack." Correct, as mentioned above, the smoother airflow is correct, the stronger, heavier fin is also correct, and the last section which refers to a deep-stall at high angles of attack is correct as well for a T-tail. "It allows for greater ground clearance when taxiing, it is a simpler design, therefore saving production cost, but it is harder to inspect after de-icing, and requires more ground handling equipment." Incorrect. Ground clearance is debatable, as an aircraft's wings are usually more of a concern for that. It is not simpler to design, as it requires a stronger fin. The last section about de-icing is correct, though. "It has a smoother airflow, therefore more predictable flight characteristics, it has a wider operating range in pitch, but requires a stronger, therefore heavier fin." Incorrect. Smoother airflow, yes; but it certainly does not have a wider operating range in pitch, as it suffers from deep-stalls, becoming useless at high angles of attack. It does require a heavier fin though.

key_points: FLUTTER AND RESONANCE Flutter is an uncontrolled oscillation that can occur on fixed surfaces, such as the wing or on control surfaces such as the ailerons or elevators
Flutter is caused by the interaction of aerodynamic forces, inertia forces and the elastic properties of the surface or structure and can lead to the catastrophic failure of the structure
An aircraft that is in the cruise will be supported by its wings and they will be bent upwards
learning.explanation: FLUTTER AND RESONANCE Flutter is an uncontrolled oscillation that can occur on fixed surfaces, such as the wing or on control surfaces such as the ailerons or elevators. Flutter is caused by the interaction of aerodynamic forces, inertia forces and the elastic properties of the surface or structure and can lead to the catastrophic failure of the structure. An aircraft that is in the cruise will be supported by its wings and they will be bent upwards. If the aircraft is subjected to a gust it will shake up and down with the wings flapping at a certain frequency. If the vibration is similar to that of the structure of the wing then it will begin to resonate. The resonance will amplify the flutter and may well lead to failure of the structure. Flutter must not occur within the normal flight operating envelope of the aircraft. Flutter can be prevented by mass balancing control surfaces to alter the moment of inertia of the surface and therefore the period of vibration (move the control surface C of G from behind the hinge to closer to the hinge). Poorly maintained aircraft, particularly those with excessive control surface backlash (play) or flexibility may mean that flutter could occur at speeds below the limit airspeed.

key_points: A wing is constantly subject to various forces; tension and compression are the main ones, but wings also experience torsion and shearing forces in some cases
When a aircraft is stationary on the ground, the wing is heavy, and is being pulled down due to gravity, wanting to droop downwards away from the fixed wing root
This means that the top surface of the wing will be under tension, as it is trying to be stretched, but the bottom surface would be under compression, as it is being squashed
learning.explanation: A wing is constantly subject to various forces; tension and compression are the main ones, but wings also experience torsion and shearing forces in some cases. When a aircraft is stationary on the ground, the wing is heavy, and is being pulled down due to gravity, wanting to droop downwards away from the fixed wing root. This means that the top surface of the wing will be under tension, as it is trying to be stretched, but the bottom surface would be under compression, as it is being squashed. This effect is increased with any increased weight of the wing, engines fitted or fuel inside the wings. The effect is reversed when flying in straight and level (1g) flight, where the wings are supending the heavy fuselage due to their ability to create lift. In this case the wings are flexing upwards away from the wing root, as can be seen very clearly on newer aircraft such as the B787 and A350. In this scenario, the upper surface of the wing is being squashed, so is under compression, where the bottom surface of the wing is under tension. This effect is increased when the lift increases (larger all-up weight, higher load factor, etc.) and also when the fuel in the wings is less, and there would be less weight resistance to the upwards flexing effect. content.question:
Which of the following can a pilot do to reduce the risk of overloading the airframe?
1. Avoid headwinds
2. Avoid large bank angles
3. Avoid turbulence
4. Fly below VA
5. Avoid tailwinds

key_points: An airframe is the combination of the whole structure of an aircraft
It undergoes many forces during flight, the largest being the lifting force from the wings
Whatever the weight of the aircraft, the wings have to be able to suspend that amount of force with lift, and the vast majority of that force goes through the two wing roots
learning.explanation: An airframe is the combination of the whole structure of an aircraft. It undergoes many forces during flight, the largest being the lifting force from the wings. Whatever the weight of the aircraft, the wings have to be able to suspend that amount of force with lift, and the vast majority of that force goes through the two wing roots. Hence, they are usually the strongest place on the entire aircraft. A very high stress scenario for the aircraft is pulling any sort of G-force, which requires increasing the load factor of the wings, and that means the lift of the wing has to increase. Large transport aircraft (CS-25) have a "limit load factor" of 2.5 G, and must be able to pull 150% of this (3.75 G) before complete structural failure occurs. This means that an aircraft will have to show during testing that the structure (mostly the wing spar and wing root) can withstand a lifting force of 3.75 times its own maximum take-off weight, which can be an incredible amount of force, before failing. Any G-force over the limit load factor is an "overload". An aircraft increases its loading during manoeuvres, so in banked turns (the greater the bank, the higher the wing loading), and any abrupt changes in direction, pitch, etc. Also, the loading increases in turbulence and any windshear. Aircraft stress obviously increases with weight, but the limiting load factor is set for the MTOW, so it can only get better as the aircraft gets lighter. VA is the manoeuvring speed, and if flying below VA, the aircraft will be unable to pull its limit load factor during a manoeuvre, as it will stall first, and therefore will not overload the airframe. Headwinds and tailwinds do not affect loading, as the aircraft just flies through the air mass it is in, and the head/tailwinds simply move the air mass forwards or backwards, increasing or decreasing groundspeed. As long as the winds do not change rapidly (windshear), this should not affect aircraft loading.

Therefore, the maximum zero-fuel weight implies a protection to the wing root against being overstressed. key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.02.04.01.13: Explain the function of floor venting (blow-out panels). Floor vents (blow-out panels) exist in an aircraft to provide a location for easy flow of air in the event of a depressurisation between the cargo hold and the passenger cabin. If a rapid depressurisation event occurred from a hole in the cargo hold, then the high pressure in the passenger cabin would push down very strongly on the floor, causing it to buckle. If the hole was in the passenger cabin, then the cargo hold high pressure would push up on the floor, again causing it to buckle. The floor vents are panels in and around the floor that easily break/open, leaving a gap where the air can equalise pressure without further damage.

content.question: Which of the following actions can be taken to reduce the chance of a tail strike during take-off?

options.A: Reduce rotation rate.
options.B: Accurately calculate take-off performance data.
options.C: Reduce the take-off speed.
options.D: Maintain a steep take-off angle after rotation.

key_points: Ensuring accurate calculation of take-off performance data is crucial for reducing the chance of a tail strike during take-off
Knowing the correct rotation speed allows pilots to smoothly lift the aircraft's nose at the right moment
If the rotation speed is too high, it can lead to an excessively steep climb angle, increasing the likelihood of a tail strike as the aircraft leaves the ground
learning.explanation: Ensuring accurate calculation of take-off performance data is crucial for reducing the chance of a tail strike during take-off. Knowing the correct rotation speed allows pilots to smoothly lift the aircraft's nose at the right moment. If the rotation speed is too high, it can lead to an excessively steep climb angle, increasing the likelihood of a tail strike as the aircraft leaves the ground. Conversely, if the rotation speed is too low, the aircraft may not achieve the desired pitch attitude for liftoff, potentially causing a tail strike as well. The two major threats for tail strikes to occur are during the landing flare/touchdown and during rotation on take-off. As many large jet transport aircraft are extended in length for larger passenger numbers, the long tail leaves very little tail margin during rotation, and factors such as crosswinds, gusty head/tailwinds and different weight and CG locations can lead to the potential for reduced tail clearance or tail strike. To mitigate this risk, pilots can choose to rotate at a slightly higher speed, if, for instance, they feel a gust just before rotation that might reduce their airspeed significantly. A higher airspeed means more airflow over the wings and therefore the aircraft will lift-off at a lower pitch angle, and the tail will therefore be further clear of the ground before reaching the tail strike angle. The pilot could also reduce the rate of rotation to further reduce the chance of tail strikes occurring (as might be done in an engine failure after V1 scenario), but this is not usually recommended in normal operation, and remember that both of these measures are not accounted for in the take-off performance calculation, so be careful not to run out of runway.

learning.explanation: The choice of material is a very important consideration when designing an aircraft. Materials all have different properties, such as their strength, elasticity, resistance to corrosion, weight, cost, heat resistance, etc. The material that is chosen for the vast majority of aircraft construction is usually metal (composites are becoming more widely used in the sector, but metal is still the bulk of the industry). Different metals have different levels of strength, they are different to work with, and are used in different sections of the aircraft. For instance, the fuselage is usually made from an easily manufactured aluminium alloy, but sections of the hot engine are made from the very expensive, but incredibly heat resistant titanium. Alloys are a clever way of combining the different properties of two or more metals to make them better for the required usage. Now to answer this question. In general, metal has a high strength to weight ratio (in that it is strong but also light). The only better type of material for strength to weight ratio is composites. Composites such as carbon fibre, aramid (Kevlar), fibreglass, and plastic composites can be made incredibly strong, but far lighter than metals. Their fibres can also be aligned to create strength in particular directions, which is much harder to do in metal. The answer is not composites though, because they are very resistant to corrosion. Metal, however, is highly susceptible to corrosion, and it is a large part of what engineers check for and treat when they maintain an aircraft.

learning.explanation: Rivets are a commonly used method of attaching two materials together, often used to attach the skin of an airframe together. There are often thousands of rivets on an aircraft, and whilst they are not know for coming off, improper maintenance or worse, improper installation would certainly make them insecure, and likely to be lost during normal operations. Corrosion is unlikely to remove rivets on its own, as they are fused to the skin, and corrosion would have to be incredibly severe (and therefore noticeable) to start removing them completely. Hard landings and high manoeuvring loads can remove rivets, screws, and other fasteners through shearing forces, for example, if the "improper maintenance or installation" option is not present in the exam, this option should be chosen. With the options as they are, hard landing and manoeuvring loads are less likely to cause the complete loss of rivets than improper maintenance or installation. Engine failure or malfunction has nothing to do with the rivets really, and they should easily be able to deal with the forces involved.

content.question: Which of the following correctly describes the construction of flight deck windshields for commercial jet aircraft?

options.A: A single sheet of toughened glass, to give the pilots the best view outwards.
options.B: Flexible vinyl only, to withstand high differential pressures.
options.C: Two or three layers separated by air, to insulate the cockpit at high altitudes.
options.D: Layers of toughened glass and vinyl, to aid impact resistance from bird strike.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.02.04.01.09: Explain why flight-deck windows are constructed with different layers. The flight deck windshield is made of many different layers of materials, mostly plastics such as acrylic and vinyl, to give it favourable properties such as high strength, good flexibility (for impact resistance) and a hard wearing outer coating, with good rain resistance. They also sometimes contain layers of toughened (tempered) glass, as it is incredibly strong, and protects well against small impacts at high speed. The layering of different materials help to provide better impact resistance than one type of material only, combining the best features of all the materials. Aircraft windshields also contain heating elements which have a couple of different jobs, their main job being to keep the plastics (vinyl and acrylic) in a slightly softer state, where they are flexible enough to absorb and deflect impacts from objects like birds at very high speeds. If the heating was not present, then the windshield would become very brittle in the extreme cold of the upper airways and could break more easily upon impact.

content.question: An operator notices corrosion on some metal parts of their aircraft fleet. What actions should they take?

options.A: Wash the aeroplanes thoroughly after each flight.
options.B: Replace the metal parts affected by corrosion with plastic or composite materials where possible.
options.C: Repair, prime and paint the damaged parts.
options.D: Paint over the corrosion to protect the area and add strength.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.02.02.01.02: State the advantages and disadvantages of composite materials compared with metal alloys by considering the following: strength-to-weight ratio; capability to tailor the strength to the direction of the load; stiffness; electrical conductivity (lightning); resistance to fatigue and corrosion; resistance to cost; discovering damage during a pre-flight inspection. The appropriate action to take if an operator notices corrosion on metal parts of their aircraft fleet is to repair, prime, and paint the damaged parts. This is important because corrosion can weaken the metal and compromise the structural integrity of the aircraft, which can be a safety hazard. Replacing the metal parts with plastic or composite materials may be an option, but it can be expensive and may not always be feasible. It is also important to note that different materials have different properties, and they may not be suitable for all applications. Washing the aircraft thoroughly after each flight may be important for general maintenance but may not prevent corrosion. A notable point is that washing the aircraft after every flight could cause some water based corrosion or rusting over time, so is not a good idea to fight corrosion. Painting over the corrosion to protect the area and add strength is not a recommended practice as it does not address the underlying corrosion issue and can lead to further damage. Therefore, the best course of action is to have the affected parts assessed by a qualified technician and have the corrosion removed and repaired, and then properly primed and painted to protect against further corrosion.

content.question: Which of the following statements is true about "plug type" aircraft doors?

options.A: They are always used in unpressurised aircraft.
options.B: Each door can move inside and outside the aircraft.
options.C: They must have a pressure relief valve.
options.D: They can only be hydraulically or electrically operated.

key_points: On pressurised aircraft, the pressure hull has to be made very strong to withstand the constant "bulging" force of the high pressure air inside
There are many potential weak points in this, including windows, hatches, and doors
Therefore, the doors in a pressurised aeroplane have to be specifically designed to seal to the frame and not break or buckle under the forces of pressurisation
learning.explanation: On pressurised aircraft, the pressure hull has to be made very strong to withstand the constant "bulging" force of the high pressure air inside. There are many potential weak points in this, including windows, hatches, and doors. Therefore, the doors in a pressurised aeroplane have to be specifically designed to seal to the frame and not break or buckle under the forces of pressurisation. This is why pressurised aircraft often use "plug type" doors, where the door is larger than the frame, and is mounted inside of the frame, so the door is being pushed into the door frame by the force of air pressure, acting like a "plug" for the hole. These doors have to be opened inwards into the aircraft, and then are usually hinged in such a way that they can go back through the door frame sideways and remain outside the aircraft whilst open. This is done primarily to reduce the space taken up inside the aircraft by the door, which also helps during an evacuation. Therefore, the most correct answer is that the door can move inside and outside the aircraft. As for the other options; They are not always used in unpressurised aircraft, in fact I imagine that is quite rare. They do not need a pressure relief valve, they are supposed to hold quite high pressure loads, and there will be an over-pressure relief valve somewhere on the aircraft fuselage. They can be manually operated, and often are.

content.question: The heating facility for the windshield of an aircraft is…

options.B: Harmful to the integrity of the windows in the event of a bird strike.
options.C: Used only at low altitudes where there is a risk of ice formation.
options.D: Only used when hot air demisting is insufficient.

learning.explanation: 021.02.04.01.10: Explain the function of window heating for structural purposes. The flight deck windshield is made of many different layers of materials, mostly plastics such as acrylic and vinyl, as well as some layers of toughened glass, to give it favourable properties such as high strength, good flexibility (for impact resistance) and a hard wearing outer coating, with good rain resistance. They also contain heating elements which have a couple of different jobs, their main job being to keep the plastics in a slightly softer state, where they are flexible enough to absorb and deflect impacts from objects like birds at very high speeds (it is therefore used on a continuous basis during the entire flight). If the heating was not present, then the windshield would become very brittle in the extreme cold of the upper airways and could break more easily upon impact. The secondary jobs of the heated windshield are de-fogging and de-icing, which are important in their own right, but are certainly a secondary consideration to the impact resistance. Another rationale for the constant operation of the window heating system is the mitigation of thermal gradients. When the window heating system is activated, it ensures that the window pane remains at a consistent temperature throughout the entirety of the flight.

content.question: Which of the following sources of hydraulic pressure is commonly used for operation of cargo doors when the electric hydraulic pumps are not working?

options.A: Hydraulic accumulator.
options.B: Hand pump.
options.C: Engine-driven pumps.
options.D: Ram air turbine.

key_points: On some large aircraft (such as the Airbus A320 family), the cargo doors are very heavy and are therefore lifted by hydraulics
They are only opened and closed on the ground, of course, so primarily this will be done with the electric hydraulic pumps providing the pressure to the system

However, if the electric hydraulic pumps are not operating (electric supply issues or pumps INOP), then the cargo doors can be opened and closed using a hand pump to provide the necessary pressure to the hydraulics
learning.explanation: On some large aircraft (such as the Airbus A320 family), the cargo doors are very heavy and are therefore lifted by hydraulics. They are only opened and closed on the ground, of course, so primarily this will be done with the electric hydraulic pumps providing the pressure to the system. However, if the electric hydraulic pumps are not operating (electric supply issues or pumps INOP), then the cargo doors can be opened and closed using a hand pump to provide the necessary pressure to the hydraulics. As for the other options: Engine driven pumps require the engines to be on, and that would be very hazardous for ground crew trying to open the cargo doors, so is not feasible. A ram air turbine is a small wind turbine that drops from the underside of an aircraft to provide power/hydraulic pressure to important controls in flight. It is not used on the ground, nor would it be useful without any airflow through it. A hydraulic accumulator would likely still have some pressure in it during most ground operations, but it is not what you would use to operate the cargo doors, as it would quickly run out of pressure and is needed for the parking brakes in some aircraft, etc.

learning.explanation: Hydraulic Accumulators are usually installed in hydraulic systems to store energy, in the form of hydraulic fluid under pressure (which will allow limited operation of hydraulic services when the pump is not operating or in case of an emergency) and to dampen out pressure fluctuations within the system. They are often used after a pump in a hydraulic system to do both these jobs, and by doing so increase efficiency and reduce the stresses on the hydraulic system. They can use a diaphragm (annex above) or a movable piston, with one side connected to the hydraulic lines and containing hydraulic fluid, but with the other side filled with gas (usually nitrogen), which can compress to the same pressure as the system. They can also help with absorbing the pressure of thermal expansion within closed hydraulic systems, when the fluid expands or contract due to temperature changes, but cannot flow back to the resevoir. key_points: Note: Please let us know if you see this in your exam, as we have reason to believe that it may be changed or removed due to appeals, thank you
Whilst this is an awful question, which pilots would usually have no business dealing with, it can still be worked out with the normal knowledge from the syllabus

A hydraulic accumulator is a device used to store hydraulic pressure, for the purposes of smoothing out hydraulic pressure changes, and storing the pressure in case there is a loss of hydraulic pump, so a finite amount of pressure remains for further uses
learning.explanation: Note: Please let us know if you see this in your exam, as we have reason to believe that it may be changed or removed due to appeals, thank you. Whilst this is an awful question, which pilots would usually have no business dealing with, it can still be worked out with the normal knowledge from the syllabus. A hydraulic accumulator is a device used to store hydraulic pressure, for the purposes of smoothing out hydraulic pressure changes, and storing the pressure in case there is a loss of hydraulic pump, so a finite amount of pressure remains for further uses. It works by compressing nitrogen inside the accumulator with the force of the hydraulic fluid, and then the high pressure nitrogen is where the energy is stored. There are a few different ways to do this, via diaphragm, with a moving piston between the fluid and the nitrogen, and with no separation at all, just gravity. These are the types of gas charged accumulators, but there are also spring accumulators and even weighted accumulators that can be used. We do not normally look into these though. If an accumulator was mounted horizontally, the gravity option would not keep the fluid in the lines, so would not work. Therefore only a diaphragm or (more likely) a moving piston would be used in this orientation. This should mean that there is no cross-contamination of nitrogen and hydraulic fluid. The hydraulic fluid stays on one side of the piston/diaphragm, the nitrogen stays on the other side. If, as in this scenario, there is an amount of hydraulic fluid leaving the nitrogen release valve, then there must have been some sort of leak between the two, for hydraulic fluid to enter the nitrogen section.

key_points: There are different ways of measuring and stating pressure

In this case, hydraulic pressure is a gauge pressure, and is therefore measured against atmospheric pressure
learning.explanation: There are different ways of measuring and stating pressure. These include; Absolute pressure, which is referenced against a vacuum, Gauge pressure, which is referenced against ambient (usually atmospheric) pressure, and Differential pressure, which measures the difference between the pressures of two different locations. In this case, hydraulic pressure is a gauge pressure, and is therefore measured against atmospheric pressure. We can also work this out by thinking about what happens when you de-pressurise a hydraulic system completely. The hydraulic pressure will read 0 PSI, as the fluid is exerting the same amount of pressure on its surroundings as the atmosphere does. Atmospheric pressure is around 14.7 PSI greater than a vacuum (i.e. its absolute pressure is 14.7 PSI, or 1013 hPa). For instance, manifold pressure gauges read out MAP (Manifold Absolute Pressure), so show the absolute ambient pressure when the engine is off. Other systems rarely read out absolute pressure.

learning.explanation: A "swash plate pump" is actually an axial piston "constant pressure" hydraulic pump, also called a "demand pump". This is the only pump that has a variable swash plate. This is the best type of hydraulic pump for aircraft hydraulic systems. It modulates its volumetric output to provide constant pressure to the system, and therefore needs no automatic cut-out valve like a constant delivery pump would. It works the same way as a constant delivery pump for the part. The inlet flow from the reservoir enters the pistons when they are furthest away, then the drive shaft spins the swash plate round so the pistons push against the fluid and this provides pressure to the hydraulic system through the outlet tube. The control piston senses the pressure in the system and adjusts the angle of the swash plate to either increase or decrease the amount of "pushing" the pistons do, thereby keeping the system pressure constant. This will become more clear if you have a look at the attached pictures. The first picture will give an overview of how this constant pressure pump looks. learning.explanation: A hydraulic filter is a component used by hydraulic systems, which is installed in the pressure and return lines, to continuously remove contaminants in the hydraulic oil. learning.explanation: ALTERNATE BRAKES Power brake actuating systems use the aircraft hydraulic system as the source of power to apply the brakes. Early aircraft had a single braking system with no backup or redundancy, meaning that any failure could result in total loss of braking capability. Nowadays, most large passenger aircraft have braking redundancy which is achieved by multiple, independent hydraulic systems backed up by accumulators. These systems allow for several layers of failure without resulting in total loss of braking capability. In most cases, the right hydraulic system supplies the normal brakes. If this is lost, there is an automatic switchover to Alternate Brakes powered by the center system. In addition to supply system redundancy, the brake accumulator is also an emergency source of power for the brakes in many power brake systems. The accumulator is pre-charged with air or nitrogen on one side of its internal diaphragm. Enough hydraulic fluid is contained on the other side of the diaphragm to operate the brakes in case of an emergency.

key_points: A "demand pump" is actually an axial piston "constant pressure" hydraulic pump
This is the only pump that has a variable swash plate
This is the best type of hydraulic pump for most aircraft hydraulic systems
learning.explanation: A "demand pump" is actually an axial piston "constant pressure" hydraulic pump. This is the only pump that has a variable swash plate. This is the best type of hydraulic pump for most aircraft hydraulic systems. It runs at a constant RPM and modulates its volumetric flow output to provide constant pressure to the system, and therefore needs no automatic cut-out valve like a constant delivery pump would. This is why it is called a "demand pump", it regulates its output based on the demand. It works the same way as a constant delivery pump for the most part. The inlet flow from the reservoir enters the pistons when they are furthest away, then the drive shaft spins the swash plate round so the pistons push against the fluid and this provides pressure to the hydraulic system through the outlet tube. The control piston senses the pressure in the system and adjusts the angle of the swash plate to either increase or decrease the amount of "pushing" the pistons do, thereby keeping the system pressure constant. This will become more clear if you have a look at the attached pictures. The first picture will give an overview of how this constant pressure pump looks. Figure 1 shows the pump at maximum stroke and figure 2 shows the pump at minimum stroke, when the system is already at the correct pressure. In terms of hydraulic pressures, most large transport aircraft have hydraulic pressures in the range of 3000 - 5000 psi as this is a good amount to power heavy control surfaces and landing gear systems, etc. Larger aircraft tend to have higher pressures in general, and the Airbus A380 runs hydraulic pressures of 5000 psi, whereas Boeing 737s run at 3000 psi.

learning.explanation: A "demand pump" is actually an axial piston "constant pressure" hydraulic pump. This is the only pump that has a variable swash plate. This is the best type of hydraulic pump for most aircraft hydraulic systems. It modulates its volumetric output to provide constant pressure to the system, and therefore needs no automatic cut-out valve like a constant delivery pump would. This is why it is called a "demand pump", it regulates its output based on the demand. It works the same way as a constant delivery pump for the most part. The inlet flow from the reservoir enters the pistons when they are furthest away, then the drive shaft spins the swash plate round so the pistons push against the fluid and this provides pressure to the hydraulic system through the outlet tube. The control piston senses the pressure in the system and adjusts the angle of the swash plate to either increase or decrease the amount of "pushing" the pistons do, thereby keeping the system pressure constant. This will become more clear if you have a look at the attached pictures. The first picture will give an overview of how this constant pressure pump looks. key_points: Axial piston pumps are constant pressure pump (variable volume)
This pump supplies fluid at a variable volume and can control the pressure
The cylinder and the drive-shaft are coaxial and rotate taking the pistons which can move up and down in the cylinder
learning.explanation: Axial piston pumps are constant pressure pump (variable volume). This pump supplies fluid at a variable volume and can control the pressure. The cylinder and the drive-shaft are coaxial and rotate taking the pistons which can move up and down in the cylinder. The pistons are a connected to shoes to the non-rotating yoke or swash plate. The angle of the swash-plate and thus the piston stroke is varied by the position of the control piston. This piston is controlled by the outlet pressure on one side of it and a spring on the other. If the pump is stationary there will be no hydraulic pressure and so the spring will push the control piston to the right and the swash-plate angle will be maximum. As the pump begins to rotate the pistons will start moving up and down because of the angle of the swash-plate. If the required operating pressure is reached, the control piston will be pushed back to the left causing the swash-plate to be almost vertical and therefore the pistons’ stroke will be minimal. This will become more clear if you have a look at the attached pictures. The first picture will give an overview of how this constant pressure pump looks. learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.04.02.01.06: Explain the purpose of main-wheel (body) steering. Larger aircraft with multiple main gear wheels often mount the main landing gear on bogie beams, which are excellent for absorbing direct impacts during landing, but can suffer from very high sideways loads during tight turns whilst taxiing. These sideways loads also put a lot of sideways stress on the tyres, which can only rotate forwards and backwards, of course, so will get unnecessarily "scrubbed" during tight turns. This effect can be reduced somewhat by giving the main gear bogie beams a small amount of available steering angle, which is only used in slow speed tight turns, turning the opposite direction of the nose wheel to turn sideways forces into longitudinal forces on the main gear assemblies, thereby reducing stress on the torsional links and reducing tyre abrasion. content.question: When the anti-skid system is inoperative, which statement below is correct?

options.A: manual braking can be used; however, the stopping distance is likely greater than with anti-skid in all surface conditions.
options.B: manual braking will result in a longer stopping distance on wet or contaminated runways only.
options.C: manual braking will result in a longer stopping distance on dry runways only.
options.D: manual braking will never ensure the required stopping distance – take-off has to be avoided.

key_points: Manual braking can be used; however, the stopping distance is likely greater than with anti-skid in all surface conditions CORRECT: with manual braking the braking distance will almost always be longer in any case, regardless of runway condition
Manual braking will never be as consistent and efficient as the auto-brake with anti-skid would
Manual braking will result in a longer stopping distance on wet or contaminated runways only
learning.explanation: Manual braking can be used; however, the stopping distance is likely greater than with anti-skid in all surface conditions CORRECT: with manual braking the braking distance will almost always be longer in any case, regardless of runway condition. Manual braking will never be as consistent and efficient as the auto-brake with anti-skid would. Manual braking will result in a longer stopping distance on wet or contaminated runways only. INCORRECT: braking distance will almost always be longer in any case, regardless of runway condition. Manual braking will result in a longer stopping distance on dry runways only. INCORRECT: braking distance will almost always be longer in any case, regardless of runway condition. Manual braking will never ensure the required stopping distance – take-off has to be avoided. INCORRECT, while manual braking significantly increases the braking distance (50%) this doesn’t mean the stopping distance available isn’t long enough. The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). There are several modes the auto-brakes can be in: Off Armed the auto-brake system is ready to be used but there are conditions which have to be met before the auto-brakes start operating. Activated When the system was armed and the necessary conditions have been met the system can be activated in different ways depending on the type of aircraft. The auto-brake system is not useable when the alternate braking system is in use. Depending on the type of aircraft, 3 to 5 modes of deceleration can be selected. Anti-skid protection is provided during autobrake operation, with inoperative anti-skid the auto-brake system will not operate. The autobrakes will be armed once a deceleration mode has been selected. When the aircraft touches down and the main wheels spin up or by the means of weight on wheels the auto-land system will be activated. The auto-land system continues to brake until a complete stop or until the auto-brakes are disarmed. The selected deceleration mode will give a standard deceleration rate independent on the weight of the aircraft for a dry runway. Disarming of the autobrakes will occur by any of the following crew actions: Manual braking Advancing any thrust lever after landing Moving the speed brake lever to down after speed brakes have been deployed on the ground. Moving the autobrake selector to Disarm or Off. When RTO is selected, the maximum brake pressure will be applied when all thrust levers a closed above a ground speed of 85 knots. So below this 85 knots the autobrakes are not activated. Manual braking When the anti-skid is inoperative the braking distance will almost always be longer in any case, regardless of runway condition. Manual braking will never be as consistent and efficient as the auto-brake with anti-skid would.

Learning Objective 021.04.01.02.06: Describe the various protection devices to avoid inadvertent gear retraction on the ground and explain the implications of taking off with one or more protection devices in place: ground lock (pins); protection devices in the gear retraction mechanism. Let's go through the options: "Insert the ground lock pins." Correct. Ground lock pins are for the landing gear when an aircraft has a retractable undercarriage, and they slot into the gear downlock system to make sure that the gear cannot retract whilst on the ground, no matter what happens to the hydraulics or external conditions. For long term storage, they must be fitted. They are part of the pilot's checks before flight, also, as leaving them in will not allow the landing gear to be raised. "Leave the parking brakes on." Incorrect. The parking brakes of an aircraft are just sealed off hydraulic fluid, and leaving them on for extended periods of time can lead to seizing of the brakes, or potentially a leak of the hydraulic fluid through small imperfections in the system, allowing the brakes to gradually release. Aircraft are chocked or tied down for long term storage. "Leave the flaps in the extended position to release the hydraulic pressure." Incorrect. Flaps should be up for long term storage, to avoid wind damage, damage to the mechanism, keep birds from nesting in the flap tracks, etc. The hydraulic pressure has nothing to do with it. "Always park the aircraft facing upwind." Whilst this is best practice, it cannot always be done, and even if you park into wind one day, for long periods of parking, the wind will change and the aircraft will no longer be into wind all the time.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.04.01.02.09: Describe some methods for emergency gear extension including: gravity/free fall; air or nitrogen pressure; manually/mechanically. The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main power system fails. There are numerous ways in which this can be done depending on the size and complexity of the aircraft. A very common way of extending the landing gear in case of emergency is by gravity free fall. Such system allows the landing gear to just drop naturally under the influence of gravity from their retracted and up-locked position to an extended and down-locked position. This is usually a one-time non-reversible operation. In order to activate this system, the aircraft will have an emergency release handle in the cockpit which connects to the gear up locks through a mechanical linkage. When operating the handles, the up-locks will be released, either by mechanical, electrical or pneumatic means. This allows each landing gear to free-fall under its own weight. The weight of the gear will also push the doors open. The gears will remain in the down and locked position because of the mechanical downlocks that come into place automatically. The doors will not retract after this, as there is no available system to do so, so they remain in the down position. There are other systems available for emergency gear extension, such as electrical or pneumatic, but gravity free-fall is so much more common due to its simplicity and lack of potential failure points. It is often aided by pneumatic pressure or a similar system to release the uplocks though.

key_points: Large aircraft have Oleo-Struts as shock absorbers, an example in the picture attached

An oleo strut consists of an inner metal tube or piston, which is attached to the wheel axle, and which moves up and down in an outer (or upper) metal tube, or cylinder, that is attached to the airframe

The cavity within the strut and piston is filled with gas (usually nitrogen, sometimes air, especially on light aircraft) and oil (usually hydraulic fluid), and is divided into two chambers that communicate through a small orifice
learning.explanation: Large aircraft have Oleo-Struts as shock absorbers, an example in the picture attached. An oleo strut consists of an inner metal tube or piston, which is attached to the wheel axle, and which moves up and down in an outer (or upper) metal tube, or cylinder, that is attached to the airframe. The cavity within the strut and piston is filled with gas (usually nitrogen, sometimes air, especially on light aircraft) and oil (usually hydraulic fluid), and is divided into two chambers that communicate through a small orifice. When the aircraft is stationary on the ground, its weight is supported by the compressed gas in the cylinder. During landing, or when the aircraft taxis over bumps, the piston slides up and down. This movement compresses the gas, which acts as a spring, and forces oil through the orifice, which acts as a damper. A tapered rod is used on some designs to change the size of the orifice as the piston moves, providing greater resistance as compression of the strut increases. Additionally, a check valve is sometimes used to uncover additional orifices so that damping during compression is less than during rebound. Oleo struts absorb and dissipate forces by converting and emitting a portion of the accumulated kinetic energy into thermal energy.

learning.explanation: The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). Autobrakes have quite a simple logic system, depending on their mode of operation, they use the wheel brakes to slow down the aircraft at a pre-determined, constant rate of deceleration (you can think of it as a constant G-force, or a constant amount of knots lost per second). This is independent on the weight of the aircraft, and the only thing that can usually hamper this is any lack of traction on the runway (wet, ice, etc.). This standard deceleration rate means that the use of any other deceleration methods will simply take some of the energy away from the brakes, making their job easier. The autobrake system does not care how easy the braking is though, it is very set on gaining a constant rate of deceleration, so applying reverse thrust would not change the rate of deceleration, it would just make the brakes cooler at the end of the landing, as they have worked less hard. The way the autobrake system controls this is by modulating the brake pressure, this is the hydraulic pressure which pushes the brake stators into the rotors. To make the brakes work less hard, the autobrake system reduces the brake pressure.

content.question: How do aircraft parking brakes work?

options.B: They reduce the hydraulic pressure applied to the brakes to that required for parking, which is much less than during landing.
options.C: They operate without hydraulic pressure by mechanically locking the brake pads to the brake disks, therefore providing plenty of braking action whilst the aircraft is parked and hydraulic power is not available.
options.D: They are independent wheel-braking systems which provides hydraulic power for braking action when the aircraft is shut down and parked.

key_points: BRAKES Most vehicle brakes work using hydraulics

On the majority of cars, this means the force you apply to the brake pedal pressurises the brake fluid (hydraulic fluid), and this pressure is used to push a piston (actuator) to force brake pads (stators) into brake discs (rotors) connected to each wheel
The harder you push the pedal, the harder the brake pads contact the discs, the more friction is caused, and the harder you decelerate
learning.explanation: BRAKES Most vehicle brakes work using hydraulics. On the majority of cars, this means the force you apply to the brake pedal pressurises the brake fluid (hydraulic fluid), and this pressure is used to push a piston (actuator) to force brake pads (stators) into brake discs (rotors) connected to each wheel. The harder you push the pedal, the harder the brake pads contact the discs, the more friction is caused, and the harder you decelerate. This is a manual braking system. In light aircraft, the same system is present, but in large aircraft, many thousands of times more braking force is needed, requiring large multi-disk brakes on many more wheels, and your feet are just not able to provide enough force to apply these brakes, no matter how much you go to the gym. This means that the brakes run off the normal hydraulic system, and your feet (or the autobrake - if fitted) are now simply moving a valve to provide more or less hydraulic pressure to the brake actuators. This means that, given large aircraft hydraulic systems can run from 3000 to 5000 psi, these can provide much more braking force, and the power comes from hydraulic pumps, not your feet. PARKING BRAKES Parking brakes operate the same in almost all aircraft, no matter whether you are using manual brakes or a hydraulically assisted system. They use a simple shut-off valve upstream of the brake actuators, and whilst the brakes are being applied, with the pads pushed into the disks, the valve is closed to trap that hydraulic pressure inside the braking system and keep those wheels stopped. The only difference is how much pressure is trapped within the brakes when you set it on. In a light aircraft, you need to push the brakes hard enough when setting the parking brake, or they might not be fully set on. Most large aircraft will not let you make this mistake. If you do leave parking brakes set on for a long time, small leaks within the system may slowly allow the pressure to drop and the brakes might slowly release, or the brakes could go the other way and seize in place, so aircraft should not have them set for too long, and instead chocks and tie-downs should be used to secure aircraft for long periods.

learning.explanation: EMERGENCY GEAR EXTENSION When you establish that the gear has failed to extend, you should be ready to use whatever type of emergency landing gear system is available in the aeroplane. The most common kinds you will see are the hand crank, hand pump hydraulic, free fall and pressurized nitrogen bottle systems. These systems are designed for emergency gear extension - not retraction. Failure of gear to retract is not an emergency unless it retracts partially and cannot be extended again A hand crank system is often found on aeroplanes with electric gear systems. The crank is employed to turn the gears that operate the actuators manually instead of through the electric motor. If you fly an aeroplane with a hydraulic system, you might use a hydraulic hand pump system to extend the gear when the primary pump fails. You do so by supplying the necessary hydraulic fluid pressure to the actuator cylinders by pumping a hand pump. A freefall system is another method of gear extension used on aeroplanes that have hydraulic gear systems. A control lever is used to open a valve that releases the system pressure. Hydraulic pressure equalizes on both sides of the gear actuators and allow the landing gear to fall into position through the force of gravity and aerodynamic loads. In the pressurized nitrogen bottle system, the nitrogen is not directly used to actuate the landing gear actuators or brake units but, instead, it applies the pressurized nitrogen to move hydraulic fluid to the actuator.

options.B: for carbon brakes to use a large number of small brake applications during taxi.

options.D: for both carbon and steel brakes to use differential braking to reduce brake temperatures.

key_points: Because the wear mechanisms are different between carbon and steel brakes, different taxi braking techniques are recommended for carbon brakes in order to maximize brake life
Steel brake wear is directly proportional to the kinetic energy absorbed by the brakes
Maximum steel brake life can be achieved during taxi by using a large number of small, light brake applications, allowing some time for brake cooling between applications
learning.explanation: Because the wear mechanisms are different between carbon and steel brakes, different taxi braking techniques are recommended for carbon brakes in order to maximize brake life. Steel brake wear is directly proportional to the kinetic energy absorbed by the brakes. Maximum steel brake life can be achieved during taxi by using a large number of small, light brake applications, allowing some time for brake cooling between applications. High airplane gross weights and high brake application speeds tend to reduce steel brake life because they require the brakes to absorb a large amount of kinetic energy. Carbon brake wear is primarily dependent on the total number of brake applications — one firm brake application causes less wear than several light applications. Maximum carbon brake life can be achieved during taxi by using a small number of long, moderately firm brake applications instead of numerous light brake applications. This can be achieved by allowing taxi speed to increase from below target speed to above target speed, then using a single firm brake application to reduce speed below the target and repeating if required, rather than maintaining a constant taxi speed using numerous brake applications. Carbon brake wear is much less sensitive to airplane weight and speed than steel brake wear.

Which of the following are features of the anti-skid system?

2. Steadily increases brake pressure as the aircraft slows

4. Release brake pressure on some wheels on a bogie to allow continued breaking on other wheels
