key_points: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value
Anti-skid system operations are based on tachometers called wheel speed sensors that measure the rotation speed of each wheel
The tachometers are connected to a computer called anti-skid unit (ASU)
learning.explanation: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value. Anti-skid system operations are based on tachometers called wheel speed sensors that measure the rotation speed of each wheel. The tachometers are connected to a computer called anti-skid unit (ASU). The ASU, by comparing the aircraft ground speed as a reference with precise wheel RPM measurements from tachometers, determines the slip ratio required for optimum braking. When a wheel begins to turn too slowly, brake pressure to this wheel is reduced. Operative anti-skid results in shorter landing distances, but also enhances take-off performance by reducing the accelerate-stop distance. In addition to the main optimised braking function, anti-skid systems offer other functions including: The ASU prevents brake application before touchdown on landing. It will prevent any brake pressure even if brake pedals are pressed before touchdown to allow the stationary wheels to spin-up to speed on contact. Only after spin-up does the ASU allow brake preassure application. The ASU protects against the locking of any wheel during the braking process by avoiding excessive wheel-slip values. The ASU protects against the effects of hydroplanning.

content.question: Consider an aircraft with hydraulically operated brakes and a pneumatically operated emergency braking system, which uses the normal hydraulic brake lines. The aircraft also has an anti-skid system to avoid loss of control and locked wheels during braking. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: The anti-skid system will allow for a lower brake temperature when braking hard.
options.B: After using the emergency braking system, the brake pedals will feel softer underfoot.
options.C: Normal braking is available after using the emergency braking system, provided it is operational.
options.D: The emergency braking system will be able to stop in a shorter distance, compared to normal braking.

key_points: Brakes on a car are operated by the driver pushing on the brake pedal, which uses a piston to squeeze hydraulic fluid into the brake lines, which then applies a force on the brake pads, pressing the pads onto the spinning disks to create friction, which gives braking action
This is, of course, a hydraulic system
Hydraulic systems are an excellent way to transfer forces around a vehicle like a car or an aircraft
learning.explanation: Brakes on a car are operated by the driver pushing on the brake pedal, which uses a piston to squeeze hydraulic fluid into the brake lines, which then applies a force on the brake pads, pressing the pads onto the spinning disks to create friction, which gives braking action. This is, of course, a hydraulic system. Hydraulic systems are an excellent way to transfer forces around a vehicle like a car or an aircraft. The main benefit of hydraulics is that the fluid is not compressible, so the force from the brake pedal piston is immediately (and completely) transferred onto the brake pads. This applies to an aircraft as well, as the only difference is that large aircraft brakes use multiple brake pads (stators) and brake disks (rotors), and the braking systems are usually supplemented by the high pressure hydraulic systems that run the rest of the aircraft's systems to gain higher forces than just the pilot's feet can produce. The emergency braking system that is mentioned in this question is to be used in the case of a loss of hydraulic pressure, and extra pressure can be gained by firing a single burst of high pressure gas into the brake lines, which then allow the brakes to be used (not nicely, but better than nothing). Because of the gas (most likely Nitrogen to reduce fire risk) now inside the hydraulic brake lines, the force applied to the pedals is not going to be completely applied to the brakes, as some of the pressure is absorbed by the compression of the gas in the lines. This makes the brakes feel "soft" or "spongy" underfoot, and not nearly as reactive or sensitive. After this is used, the brake lines will have to be bled again to remove the remaining air in the system, and replace it completely with hydraulic fluid. The gas canister will be replaced for emergency brake system use in the future. Mention of the anti-skid system is there to throw you off. Anti-skid improves braking by stopping the wheels from locking up, so actually increases brake temperature (or does not affect it, depending on the conditions).

Learning Objective 021.04.01.02.08: Describe the sequence for emergency gear extension: unlocking; operating; down-locking. All aircraft are different in their emergency gear extension, but on the whole, the concept is the same. The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main power system fails. Many system allows the landing gear to essentially "free fall" under the influence of gravity from their retracted and up-locked position to an extended and down-locked position. This is usually a one-time non-reversable operation. We are assuming that "activating the uplocks" in this sense refers to the mechanical unlocking process of the gear uplocks. This is usually a cable that is pulled from the flight deck by some means, which overcomes the spring tension on the uplock, releasing the gear (and/or gear doors) to extend by gravity. Another consideration is that of the hydraulic system, as usually landing gear is held up during flight by a combination of the mechanical up-locks and the hydraulic pressure being sealed off within the actuators. To release the gear for free fall, the correct sequence of actions would usually be: Release the hydraulic cut-off valve holding the hydraulic pressure (not the selector valves, they are different) Release the locks holding the undercarriage doors (if fitted). Release the mechanical uplocks holding the gear up. One or all of these items may have to be performed manually, using mechanical pulley systems. Compressed gas can also be fired for the purposes of releasing mechanical up-locks.

The airbus A320 doesn't have a named RTO mode, but MAX is only ever used for RTOs and it engages when the ground spoilers deploy, which is at or above 72 kt and with thrust levers set to idle. They are all very similar systems, with small variations. The autobrake applies maximum braking and it can be disconnected at any time by the pilot, who can then apply brakes manually. It does not provide a constant rate of deceleration as the landing autobrake modes attempt to do. You could argue that it "applies the anti-skid maximum braking" as anti-skid would reduce the brake pressure if the traction is not good enough, but this is not mentioned and we would consider this a less correct answer, particularly after looking at the learning objectives and previous questions.

content.question: After landing, with the autobrake system set to a constant deceleration rate, the use of thrust reversers will...

options.A: decrease the brake pressure.
options.B: change the configuration of the ground spoilers.
options.C: increase the landing distance.
options.D: increase the brake pressure.

key_points: Note: This is quite similar to Q215119, but has a couple of small changes to the question and options, so we have added it separately
The correct answer is the same
The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO)
learning.explanation: Note: This is quite similar to Q215119, but has a couple of small changes to the question and options, so we have added it separately. The correct answer is the same. The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). Autobrakes have quite a simple logic system, depending on their mode of operation, they use the wheel brakes to slow down the aircraft at a pre-determined, constant rate of deceleration (you can think of it as a constant G-force, or a constant amount of knots lost per second). This is independent on the weight of the aircraft, and the only thing that can usually hamper this is any lack of traction on the runway (wet, ice, etc.). This standard deceleration rate means that the use of any other deceleration methods will simply take some of the energy away from the brakes, making their job easier. The autobrake system does not care how easy the braking is though, it is very set on gaining a constant rate of deceleration, so applying reverse thrust would not change the rate of deceleration, it would just make the brakes cooler at the end of the landing, as they have worked less hard. The way the autobrake system controls this is by modulating the brake pressure, this is the hydraulic pressure which pushes the brake stators into the rotors. To make the brakes work less hard, the autobrake system reduces the brake pressure.

key_points: The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main power system fails
There are numerous ways in which this is done depending on the size and complexity of the aircraft
A means of extending the landing gear and locking it in the down position in case of emergency is by gravity free fall
learning.explanation: The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main power system fails. There are numerous ways in which this is done depending on the size and complexity of the aircraft. A means of extending the landing gear and locking it in the down position in case of emergency is by gravity free fall. Such system allows the landing gear to essentially "free fall" under the influence of gravity from their retracted and up-locked position to an extended and down-locked position. This is usually a one-time non-reversable operation. In order to activate this system, the aircraft will have an emergency release handle in the cockpit which connects to the gear up locks and hydraulic locks through a mechanical linkage. These can be used to allow the gears to free-fall under their own weight. The weight of the gears will push the doors open. The gears will remain in the down and locked position by mechanical means, these down-locks work automatically and mechanically once the gear reaches the down position. Another consideration is that of the hydraulic system, as usually landing gear is held up during flight by a combination of the mechanical up-locks and the hydraulic pressure being sealed off within the actuators. To release the gear for free fall, the correct sequence of actions would usually be: Release the hydraulic cut-off valve holding the hydraulic pressure. Release the locks holding the undercarriage doors (if fitted). Release the mechanical uplocks holding the gear up. One or all of these items may have to be performed manually, using mechanical pulley systems. Compressed gas can also be fired for the purposes of releasing mechanical up-locks.

While this question may be type-specific, the learning objectives offer limited room for discussion as you can read above. Automatic Braking (Autobrake) systems offer two modes of operation: Landing Mode Rejected Take-Off (RTO) Mode In Landing Mode (1, 2, 3, MAX), calibrated pressure is automatically applied to the brakes upon touchdown, regardless of pilot input. This system adjusts brake pressure to counteract aircraft drag, thrust reversers, and spoilers, maintaining the chosen deceleration level for modes 1, 2 and 3 and maximum braking for MAX. The Rejected Take-Off (RTO) setting instructs the autobrake system to apply full pressure to the wheel brakes, bringing the aircraft to a stop. Activation of RTO mode occurs when a rejected takeoff is initiated by the pilot at a groundspeed exceeding 88 knots. Note: On a Boeing 737, the 1, 2, 3, and MAX deceleration positions control the autobrake system during landing, modulating brake pressure to achieve specified deceleration rates until the aircraft comes to a complete stop. Regarding other options, the use of reverse thrust and autobrake is not mutually exclusive - Flight crews can employ reverse thrust in conjunction with autobrake for maximum deceleration. content.question: On landing gear, most stress is carried by a torsion link...

options.A: on the inner cylinder of the main oleo leg during a small radius turn.
options.B: on the outer cylinder of the main oleo leg during a small radius turn.
options.C: on the inner cylinder of the main oleo leg during a large radius turn.
options.D: between the inner and outer cylinder of the main oleo leg during a small radius turn.

key_points: The torsion link on landing gear is the component shown in the annex above which stops the gear twisting round under load
Without the torsion link, there would be no directional control over the landing gear, and it would be free to spin around
With the wheel connected to the inner cylinder of the oleo, and the aircraft connected to the outer cylinder, there would be no mechanical connection between the two, only a little friction
learning.explanation: The torsion link on landing gear is the component shown in the annex above which stops the gear twisting round under load. Without the torsion link, there would be no directional control over the landing gear, and it would be free to spin around. With the wheel connected to the inner cylinder of the oleo, and the aircraft connected to the outer cylinder, there would be no mechanical connection between the two, only a little friction. The torsion link provides that mechanical connection between the inner and the outer cylinder (the wheel and the aircraft) in only one direction, preventing sideways movement, whilst still allowing shock absorption by the oleo in the up and down direction, as it moves in and out due to its "scissor link" design. The torsion link does carry lots of stress, therefore, when the aircraft wants to turn and the wheel does not. For example, a main wheel (without steering capability) going round a tight corner where the aircraft wants to twist sideways but the wheel does not. Even more than this, a bogie beam with multiple attached landing gear going round a similarly small corner, would have huge amounts of stress through the torsion link.

The defects which may make the cover unserviceable are: Cuts. Cuts in the tyre cover penetrating to the cords render the tyre unserviceable and must be repaired. Note: If you find cuts in the tire, it’s important to make sure that they haven’t cut into the ply of the tire. Any deep cuts extending more than half the width of a rib and deeper than 50 percent of the remaining tread depth are indications for tire replacement. In this case, we believe the examiner is referring to superficial cuts which would make the tyre still airworthy. Bulges. These may indicate partial failure of the casing, if the casing has failed. Foreign Bodies. Embedded stones, metal, glass etc. These must NOT be removed but reported to maintenance staff. Wear. Pattern tread covers worn to the base of the marker grooves or marker tie bars for 25% of the tyre circumference, or plain tread covers worn to the casing fabric, must not be used. Creep. Movement of the tyre round the wheel must not exceed 1 in for tyres of up to 24 in outside diameter and 1 1⁄2 in for tyres over 24 in outside diameter. If these limits are exceeded, the tyre must be removed from the wheel and the tube examined for signs of tearing at the valve. "5. Oil contamination on the tyre surface" Correct. Oil contamination (i.e. brake oil, fuel, tar oil, solvents, chemicals) can degrade the rubber of the tire. Typically, the standard approach involves cleaning the tire with Isopropyl Alcohol. However, if the tire becomes sticky, it becomes necessary to replace the wheel. Hydrocarbons have a detrimental effect on rubber, causing it to lose its essential properties, thereby reducing tire performance.

content.question: Which of these statements about an auto-brake system is correct?

options.A: When a low auto-brake setting is used during landing use of reverse will not influence the brake temperature
options.B: On most aeroplanes the auto-brake system provides the capability to select a fixed landing distance
options.C: The achievable deceleration levels of full manual braking and the auto-brake RTO mode are the same
options.D: When using manual braking during taxiing, the auto-brake system will disarm

key_points: “When a low auto-brake setting is used during landing use of reverse will not influence the brake temperature
” INCORRECT

It obviously will, the autobrake varies the brake pressure to achieve a constant deceleration, so therefore, if you’re using thrust reversers, some of that energy (to dissipate speed to achieve a certain deceleration rate) is being supplied by the use of thrust reversers – therefore, they reduce the amount of brake pressure which has to be applied on the brakes => brake temperature will reduce as a result of using reversers
learning.explanation: “When a low auto-brake setting is used during landing use of reverse will not influence the brake temperature.” INCORRECT. It obviously will, the autobrake varies the brake pressure to achieve a constant deceleration, so therefore, if you’re using thrust reversers, some of that energy (to dissipate speed to achieve a certain deceleration rate) is being supplied by the use of thrust reversers – therefore, they reduce the amount of brake pressure which has to be applied on the brakes => brake temperature will reduce as a result of using reversers. “When using manual braking during taxiing, the auto-brake system will disarm” INCORRECT. During taxi we only ever use manual braking, therefore, the reference to the use of autobrake during taxi does not make sense. “On most aeroplanes the auto-brake system provides the capability to select a fixed landing distance” INCORRECT. Only a few aircraft do that, I believe the A350 and A380 – where you can actually go into the computer and say “this is the runway we are landing on, and I actually want to vacate at this specific exit” because it has the runway in the database and all the different taxiways off the runway and, therefore, you can use the autobrake and select to vacate at a certain exit and it will make sure you have the right speed to vacate => but that is not the majority of the aeroplanes. Ultimately, it is not very practical because there are a lot of different factors. On most aircrafts, it just provides a fixed deceleration rate but not a fixed landing distance (seen it is subjected to wind as well). You can never say it will precisely take this xxx amount of distance. Hopefully, this makes sense. “The achievable deceleration levels of full manual braking and the auto-brake RTO mode are the same” CORRECT. So if you press on the pedals as hard as you possibly can, it’s going to give you a maximum deceleration rate and it will also ensure that the wheels don’t lock up – which is exactly the same as autobrake max/RTO. If you look at the pushbutton, it says MAX - maximum amount of braking so it is the same as if you push on the pedals as hard as you can. (Don’t forget that you’ve got antiskid which works in conjunction with autobrake as well) => Fundamentally, if autobrake is in rejected take off RTO mode and you reject the take off => then the braking will be maximum possible braking, which is exactly the same as if you press on the pedals maximum. But the thing with the autobrake is that, as soon as the pilot decides to reject the take off and closes the thrust levers, then the maximum braking pressure gets applied immediately. Whereas, if you were to take off without autobrake, and then decided to abort the take-off, you’d first think about “right, I have got to close the thrust levers” and then you’ve got to think to press on the brake pedals => so, there’s obviously an element of delay in that. And that is why the stopping distance in the event of a manual rejected take off would be greater, even though the brake pressure on the brakes, would be exactly the same under both circumstances. content.question: What happens if the grooves or tread of an aircraft tyre are worn?

options.A: The tyre can be used on the nose wheel only.
options.B: The tyre can never be repaired or retreaded.
options.C: The tyre can be retreaded several times.
options.D: The tyre can be retreaded once.

key_points: The tread of an airplane tire will wear out long before its casing (everything other than the tread)
This means that the tire casing remains entirely capable of safely holding the inflation pressure to support the load of the airplane long after the tread has worn away
All the tire needs is a new tread
learning.explanation: The tread of an airplane tire will wear out long before its casing (everything other than the tread). This means that the tire casing remains entirely capable of safely holding the inflation pressure to support the load of the airplane long after the tread has worn away. All the tire needs is a new tread. Airplane tires can be expensive: there is no logical reason to scrap a tire for an aircraft when it can be safely and economically reconditioned with a new tread. This is why retreading has been standard practice in the aviation industry for decades. The maximum retread level for the part number is set only after extensive testing and analysis. Some airplane tyres can be safely retreaded up to seven or more times, but there is always a limit and the limit is always set with an abundance of caution. The retread process is easy to understand. A worn tyre is removed from an aircraft. It is sent back to a retreading firm, often a manufacturer of airplane tires. When the firm receives a tire for retreading it is carefully inspected to ensure that it is safe and economical to retread. The tyre is scrapped if technicians consider there to be doubt about its airworthiness.

learning.explanation: The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main power system fails. There are numerous ways in which this is done depending on the size and complexity of the aircraft. A means of extending the landing gear and locking it in the down position in case of emergency is by gravity free fall. key_points: EMERGENCY GEAR EXTENSION When you establish that the gear has failed to extend, you should be ready to use whatever type of emergency landing gear system is available in the aeroplane
The most common kinds you will see are the hand crank, hand pump hydraulic, free fall and pressurized nitrogen bottle systems
These systems are designed for emergency gear extension - not retraction
learning.explanation: EMERGENCY GEAR EXTENSION When you establish that the gear has failed to extend, you should be ready to use whatever type of emergency landing gear system is available in the aeroplane. The most common kinds you will see are the hand crank, hand pump hydraulic, free fall and pressurized nitrogen bottle systems. These systems are designed for emergency gear extension - not retraction. Failure of gear to retract is not an emergency unless it retracts partially and cannot be extended again In the pressurized nitrogen bottle system, the emergency gear extension system is activated by pulling the red EMER GEAR CONTROL handle, allowing a one shot extension of the landing gear. Once activated, nitrogen pressure from the emergency air bottle is released through a shuttle valve to the extend side of the landing gear actuators, extending the gear towards the down and locked position. Once the gear has fully extended, the down locks inside the actuators will engage and the down and locked micro switches will be energised causing the three green down and locked lights to illuminate. Once the emergency gear extension procedure has been used, subsequent retraction of the landing gear cannot be achieved. Ground servicing of the system is required prior to normal use of the system.

content.question:
Which of the following statements about an anti-skid system are correct/incorrect?
(1) The anti-skid computer compares wheel speed to aeroplane reference speed to provide a slip ratio for maximum braking performance
(2) If a pilot is careful when braking manually, he/she will be able to achieve the same braking efficiency as if braking with anti-skid

options.A: (1) is incorrect; (2) is incorrect.
options.B: (1) is correct; (2) is incorrect.
options.C: (1) is correct; (2) is correct.
options.D: (1) is incorrect; (2) is correct.

key_points: ANTI-SKID SYSTEM Large aircraft with power brakes require anti-skid systems
It is not possible to immediately ascertain in the flight deck when a wheel stops rotating and begins to skid, especially in aircrafts with multiple-wheel main landing gear assemblies
A skid not corrected can quickly lead to a tire blowout, possible damage to the aircraft, and control of the aircraft may be lost
learning.explanation: ANTI-SKID SYSTEM Large aircraft with power brakes require anti-skid systems. It is not possible to immediately ascertain in the flight deck when a wheel stops rotating and begins to skid, especially in aircrafts with multiple-wheel main landing gear assemblies. A skid not corrected can quickly lead to a tire blowout, possible damage to the aircraft, and control of the aircraft may be lost. One of the important issues to realize is that the anti-skid system greatly increases the effectiveness of braking. In very simplified terms, the anti-skid system provides the greatest possible brake pressure while not allowing the wheels to lock due to an excessive brake pressure being applied. Without the anti-skid system (manual braking) the braking effectiveness is reduced. "The anti-skid computer compares wheel speed to aeroplane reference speed to provide a slip ratio for maximum braking performance." Correct. These systems use a computer that, during ground movement when braking, which constantly compares the measured values of individual wheels (actual rotational speed) with the desired optimum parameters, providing a slip ratio for maximum braking performance. "If a pilot is careful when braking manually, he/she will be able to achieve the same braking efficiency as if braking with anti-skid." Incorrect. A pilot will never reach the same performance as a properly functioning anti-skid system. The anti-skid system senses when a brake starts to skid and will reduce braking pressure to avoid the wheels from skidding, a pilot won’t come close to the same performance.

content.question: Landing gear torsion links are used to…

options.A: control the rate of oleo strut recoil.
options.B: prevent rotation of the landing gear piston in the oleo strut.
options.C: absorb the lateral stresses to which the gear is subjected.
options.D: prevent extension of the oleo strut when the gear is retracted.

key_points: The function of a torsion link, or torque link, is to avoid movement of the inner cylinder within the outer cylinder
So when the aircraft is moving forward without turning there will not be much force on the torsion link
When the aircraft touches down with a strong cross-wind there might be some forces on the torque link, but most of the movement will be forward in line with the direction of the aircraft
learning.explanation: The function of a torsion link, or torque link, is to avoid movement of the inner cylinder within the outer cylinder. So when the aircraft is moving forward without turning there will not be much force on the torsion link. When the aircraft touches down with a strong cross-wind there might be some forces on the torque link, but most of the movement will be forward in line with the direction of the aircraft. When the aircraft is turning on the ground and especially turns with a small radius, the wheels will want to move forward whilst the aircraft is turning, this will cause a lot of load on the torsion link.

learning.explanation: Basic auto-brake information below, which states that the auto-brake system is only disarmed by Pilot action. The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). There are several modes the auto-brakes can be in: Off Armed the auto-brake system is ready to be used but there are conditions which have to be met before the auto-brakes start operating. Activated When the system was armed and the necessary conditions have been met the system can be activated in different ways depending on the type of aircraft. The auto-brake system is not useable when the alternate braking system is in use. Depending on the type of aircraft, 3 to 5 modes of deceleration can be selected. Anti-skid protection is provided during autobrake operation, with inoperative anti-skid the auto-brake system will not operate. The autobrakes will be armed once a deceleration mode has been selected. When the aircraft touches down and the main wheels spin up or by the means of weight on wheels the auto-land system will be activated. The auto-land system continues to brake until a complete stop or until the auto-brakes are disarmed. Disarming of the autobrakes will occur by any of the following crew actions: Manual braking Advancing any thrust lever after landing Moving the speed brake lever to down after speed brakes have been deployed on the ground. content.question: Light aircraft and helicopters may equipped with a “blowdown” emergency gear extension system for use in case of hydraulic failure. Which gasses are used for this purpose, and how are the gasses sent to the actuators?

options.A: Nitrogen or compressed air, which is routed through a manually operated shuttle valve.
options.B: Helium or nitrogen, which is routed to parallel actuators on the landing gear.
options.C: Nitrogen or compressed air, which is routed to parallel actuators on the landing gear.
options.D: Helium or carbon dioxide, which is routed through a manually operated shuttle valve.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.04.01.02.09: Describe some methods for emergency gear extension including: gravity/free fall; air or nitrogen pressure; manually/mechanically. The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main hydraulic system fails. There are numerous ways in which this can be done depending on the size and complexity of the aircraft. A very common way of extending the landing gear in case of emergency is by gravity free fall. This is common for large aircraft as their gear are very heavy. Unfortunately, in light aircraft, the gear components are not as heavy, so can get jammed in place with not very much force. This includes the "blowdown" system using compressed gasses. The action of emergency gear extension is often a one-way movement, and cannot be reversed. In order to activate the system, the aircraft will have an emergency release handle in the cockpit which connects to the gear up locks through one of the following systems. When operating the handles, the up-locks will be released, either by mechanical, electrical or pneumatic means. This allows each landing gear to free-fall under its own weight. Some emergency extension systems (as mentioned above) use bottles of compressed air or compressed nitrogen to extend the gear, thereby overcoming any small jams that would otherwise keep the gear in the up position. Nitrogen is better as it is non-flammable, and air contains oxygen, which will feed a potential fire. Compressed air is easier (and cheaper) to bottle though. The gear will remain in the down and locked position because of the mechanical down locks that come into place automatically. The doors will not retract after this, as there is no available system to do so, so they remain in the down position. The shuttle valve mentioned in this question is a way to feed one actuator with two different pressure sources. When one pressure source loses pressure, the piston can slide across from blocking the emergency source to blocking the usual source, allowing out the emergency pressure to feed the actuator. This can be automatic or manually controlled. A diagram of the shuttle valve is shown in the annex above.

options.C: Decreased on the slower turning wheels.

key_points: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value

The tachometers are connected to a computer called anti-skid unit (ASU)
learning.explanation: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value. Anti-skid system operations are based on tachometers called wheel speed sensors that measure the rotation speed of each wheel. The tachometers are connected to a computer called anti-skid unit (ASU). The ASU, by comparing the aircraft ground speed as a reference with precise wheel RPM measurements from tachometers, determines the slip ratio required for optimum braking. When a wheel begins to turn too slowly, brake pressure to this wheel is reduced. Operative anti-skid results in shorter landing distances, but also enhances take-off performance by reducing the accelerate-stop distance.

content.question: The retraction mechanism of the landing gear is...

options.A: an active system and operated with the engine pump.
options.B: an active system and operated with the pressure pump.
options.C: a passive system and operated with the engine pump.
options.D: a passive system and operated with the pressure pump.

key_points: In all aircraft, the landing gear is an active system, in that it requires a power source to function, in this case, it is hydraulic pressure that powers it
The landing gear in some aircraft can be lowered passively (gravity extension), but cannot be raised passively
The power for the hydraulic system in all large aircraft comes from engine driven pumps
learning.explanation: In all aircraft, the landing gear is an active system, in that it requires a power source to function, in this case, it is hydraulic pressure that powers it. The landing gear in some aircraft can be lowered passively (gravity extension), but cannot be raised passively. The power for the hydraulic system in all large aircraft comes from engine driven pumps. These pumps are driven by the auxiliary gearbox connected to one of the engine shafts. Electric hydraulic pumps are also present, and provide the same amount of pressure, but have a much lower displacement as they are much smaller, weaker pumps. Therefore, when landing gear is raised, the vast majority of the load is placed on the engine driven pumps, and is therefore fed by power from the auxiliary gearbox.

7 m/sec2 on the A320 in low autobrake mode)
Therefore, on a dry runway, when you select “low” autobrake mode in flight, on the landing roll, autobrake varies the brake pressure to achieve that deceleration rate always
learning.explanation: The autobrake system varies the brake pressure to achieve a deceleration rate (about 1.7 m/sec2 on the A320 in low autobrake mode). Therefore, on a dry runway, when you select “low” autobrake mode in flight, on the landing roll, autobrake varies the brake pressure to achieve that deceleration rate always. However, if the runway is contaminated and has slippery spots, brakes might be released in order to prevent skidding. Brake release will consequently reduce deceleration rate. Fundamentally, it will provide the highest deceleration it can achieve, taking into consideration runway condition.

key_points: Undercarriage locks Any retractable undercarriage has to be locked when in the up (retracted) and down (extended) positions
Types of lock Over centre Lock The over-centre lock or "geometric lock" is mainly used as a downlock
It will require a mechanical force to release the lock
learning.explanation: Undercarriage locks Any retractable undercarriage has to be locked when in the up (retracted) and down (extended) positions. Types of lock Over centre Lock The over-centre lock or "geometric lock" is mainly used as a downlock. It will require a mechanical force to release the lock. The locks can be formed by using the stays bracing struts. They do not require much to lock, so are used also in the case of emergency gear extension, as they will lock as soon as the gear is fully extended. They allow the side- or front-stays to be kept in line using a very small locking force, which means the main stays remain strong Hook Lock The hook lock will lock automatically, without hydraulic pressure, but require hydraulic pressure input to unlock. These type of locks are normally used as uplocks, but they can rarely be used as a downlock.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct with regards to the autobrake system during landing?

options.A: If used at low settings, use of a reverser will have NO effect.
options.B: It is possible to choose a fixed stopping distance.
options.C: It will remain active until the aircraft comes to a stop, unless disconnected by the pilot.
options.D: It is disconnected automatically if thrust reversers are used.

key_points: Autobrake is a system where the pilots do not press the aircraft brakes at all, the aircraft instead modulates its own brake pressure to maintain a selected rate of deceleration
There are multiple levels of braking available, for progressively shorter runways, requiring a progressively higher rate of deceleration
Anti-skid must be operative for autobrake to work
learning.explanation: Autobrake is a system where the pilots do not press the aircraft brakes at all, the aircraft instead modulates its own brake pressure to maintain a selected rate of deceleration. There are multiple levels of braking available, for progressively shorter runways, requiring a progressively higher rate of deceleration. Anti-skid must be operative for autobrake to work. The autobrake cannot control the aircraft laterally, so it would be really bad if the wheels locked up (on a wet runway without anti-skid), and therefore it cannot be used at all if anti-skid is not available. Autobrakes will be disarmed during use by any of the following conditions: Manual braking Advancing any thrust lever after landing Moving the speed brake lever to down after speed brakes have been deployed on the ground. Moving the autobrake selector to Disarm or Off. Otherwise, the autobrake system will continue meeting a selected rate of deceleration until making a complete stop. Whilst one of the other options mentions setting a fixed stopping distance, this is a lot more complex than it sounds, but a system like this has been implemented on newer Airbus A380 and A350 aircraft called BTV (Brake to Vacate). EASA are not yet including this in the learning objectives or questions, so assume it does not exist for the ATPL exams.

learning.explanation: A pilot's pre-flight inspection of the aircraft should conclude whether the wheels and tyres are suitable for the flight. External damage such as flat-spots, embedded objects, cuts or bulges in the sidewall can make any tyre unsuitable to be used. The tread of the tyre is the rubber section which contacts the floor, usually with grooves or a pattern in it to clear water. It is a key component for protecting the other parts of the tyre. The sidewall is the bit on the side of the tyre that connects the tread to the "bead", which is fitted to the wheel rim, it is a very vulnerable section of the tyre, with less protection. Objects embedded in the tyre cause obvious damage to the structural integrity, which could lead to blow outs or slow punctures, both of which are very bad for any ground movements, take off and landing. Note: We are well aware that the pilot should check for both embedded objects and tyre creep when performing their walk around, so would be inclined to appeal this question if it came up in this format. We believe that embedded items are worse than tyre creep, but they should certainly both be checked. Any further exam feedback about this question would be useful to check what EASA are choosing as correct, as well as their choice of options in the future.

What is the input data of the Anti-skid system?
1. Wheel speed
2. Groundspeed
3. Wheel speed of all the wheels on the boogie
4. Tire pressure
5. Brake temperature

key_points: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value
Anti-skid system operations are based on tachometers called wheel speed sensors that measure the rotation speed of each wheel
The tachometers are connected to a computer called anti-skid unit (ASU)
learning.explanation: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value. Anti-skid system operations are based on tachometers called wheel speed sensors that measure the rotation speed of each wheel. The tachometers are connected to a computer called anti-skid unit (ASU). The ASU, by comparing the aircraft ground speed as a reference with precise wheel RPM measurements from tachometers, determines the slip ratio required for optimum braking. Operative anti-skid results in shorter landing distances, but also enhances take-off performance by reducing the accelerate-stop distance.

The original feedback did not compare the multi-disk steel brakes to anything, so was very difficult to answer as the options require comparison to other brakes, however, it was clear from the options that sometimes the examiner was asking about the multi-disk vs single disk element, and sometimes about steel brakes vs carbon brakes. Therefore, We chose to compare them to single disc carbon brakes. The only difference in answer can occur if they compare multi-disc steel brakes to multi-disc carbon brakes directly, in which case the carbon brakes have higher braking strength usually. Please let us know what was actually on the exam if you do see this, and we can adjust it as necessary, thanks! The two usual materials for aircraft brakes are steel and carbon. They vary somewhat in characteristics, and in cost. Steel brakes are usually much cheaper than carbon brakes. Steel brakes perform better at lower temperatures, and when they get hot, suffer from brake fade, where the rotors do not apply as much traction onto the stators due to the intense heat. Carbon brakes, however, have a much hotter operating window. In fact, carbon brakes are not very effective at low temperatures, so need to have some heat in them already, to be able to produce the peak braking force. This is why the two types should be treated differently. Steel brakes should be kept cool, by using them many times, but softly with gaps to allow them to cool. Carbon brakes, on the other hand, should be applied firmly all at once when possible, to allow them to work in their operating window as much as possible, and because their wear is more linked to amount of applications, rather than total heat input. In most transport aircraft, the brakes need to absorb vast amounts of heat during landings, rejected take-offs and taxiing, much more than could be absorbed by a single disk and pair of brake pads. Therefore, their brakes are usually made up of multiple (spinning) brake discs separated by multiple (static) rings of brake pads. These multiple rings of stators and rotors can provide much stronger braking and absorb far more heat than a single disc and pair of pads alone, steel or carbon.

key_points: Pre-flight inspections must confirm whether the condition of the tyre is suitable for operation
Tyre covers must be examined for cuts, bulges, embedded stones, metal or glass, signs of wear, creep, local sponginess, etc
Operation with damaged tyres may result in tyre burst that can cause further damage to the airframe or lead to a ground collision/runway excursion
learning.explanation: Pre-flight inspections must confirm whether the condition of the tyre is suitable for operation. Tyre covers must be examined for cuts, bulges, embedded stones, metal or glass, signs of wear, creep, local sponginess, etc. Operation with damaged tyres may result in tyre burst that can cause further damage to the airframe or lead to a ground collision/runway excursion. The defects which may make the cover unserviceable are: Cuts. Cuts in the tyre cover penetrating to the cords render the tyre unserviceable and must be repaired. Bulges. These may indicate partial failure of the casing, if the casing has failed. Foreign Bodies. Embedded stones, metal, glass etc. These must NOT be removed but reported to maintenance staff. Wear. Pattern tread covers worn to the base of the marker grooves or marker tie bars for 25% of the tyre circumference, or plain tread covers worn to the casing fabric, must not be used. Creep. Movement of the tyre round the wheel must not exceed 1 in for tyres of up to 24 in outside diameter and 1 1⁄2 in for tyres over 24 in outside diameter. If these limits are exceeded, the tyre must be removed from the wheel and the tube examined for signs of tearing at the valve. A check of the ply/speed rating, tread depth measurement, and tyre pressure measurement is usually the job of an engineer, and is not required before every single flight, however checking tyre creep and embedded objects are quick enough, and important enough tasks to require a check of every tyre before flight.

The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). Activated When the system was armed and the necessary conditions have been met the system can be activated in different ways depending on the type of aircraft. key_points: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the Fly-By-Wire control system
As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a known output for if both pilots make inputs at once

learning.explanation: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the Fly-By-Wire control system. As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a known output for if both pilots make inputs at once. Please let us know if you see either in the exam, and whatever you can remember about them, thank you! FLY-BY-WIRE In a Fly-By-Wire aircraft, the pilot inputs commands via a sidestick or yoke to a computer. The computer then processes these inputs and sends corresponding electrical signals to the servo valve which in turn controls the movement of a hydraulic actuator, moving the flight control surface. There are numerous advantages to fly by wire systems, including weight savings and safety features that can be incorporated into the computer software. FBW enables highly reliable flight envelope protection systems which significantly enhances safety. For instance, on the Airbus, the flight mode of Normal Law provides five types of protection: pitch attitude, load factor limitations, high speed, high-AoA and bank angle. In addition, Low Speed Protection is available in certain phases of flight. The bank angle protection system on a FBW aircraft can change the effect of control inputs to make it harder to maintain a bank angle that is outside of limits. For instance, in the Airbus A320, above 33°, force is needed to maintain the bank angle. The aircraft will not allow bank angles past 67° in normal law. In this question the bank angle protections have activated improperly at 30° AoB, so more force will be required to maintain or increase the angle of bank.

content.question: In a fully manual flight control system, the pilot must exert sufficient force to...

options.A: separate each pilot`s yaw control in the case of a jam.
options.B: overcome the aerodynamic loads felt at the control surface.
options.C: activate the artificial feel system.
options.D: allow pressure to build up in the flight control actuators.

key_points: As a fully manual flight control system is reversible the pilot feels all forces acting on the control surfaces in the controls
So the pilot must be able to exert sufficient force to overcome the aerodynamic loads on the control surfaces
Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude
learning.explanation: As a fully manual flight control system is reversible the pilot feels all forces acting on the control surfaces in the controls. So the pilot must be able to exert sufficient force to overcome the aerodynamic loads on the control surfaces. Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude. The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls. The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible. This means that a force applied to the controls is a force which moves the control surface, and also a force which moves the control surface will move the pilot’s controls. This means that the air pressure on the control surface can be felt in the pilot’s controls. When the flight controls are fully power operated this is not the case and is called irreversible. This means that if there is a force moving the control surface this will not move the control columns, and there will be no natural feel on the controls. Because of this there will need to be an artificial feel unit installed in a fully powered or irreversible control system. This artificial feel unit should apply force to the cockpit controls in proportion to the control deflection and in proportion to the aircraft’s speed. This artificial feel system will also work with a trim system, but this works different than a normal trim surface does. A movement of the trimwheel will result in a movement of the electric trim actuator, and so the control surface, but not in the movement of the control column (this is for elevator control). It is different for aileron and rudder trim. Elevator trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim)

content.question: What happens to the flight envelope protection if your aircraft system turns to the Alternate mode?

options.A: degraded.
options.B: fully maintained.
options.C: lost.
options.D: upgraded.

key_points: EASA examinations use the Airbus A320 family as an example of Fly-By-Wire controlled aircraft
Normal law is the system mode which is active throughout the flight and is terminated when system failures occur that prevent its use
The highest reduced mode of operation in Airbus FBW systems is the Alternate Law, which provides most features of normal law
learning.explanation: EASA examinations use the Airbus A320 family as an example of Fly-By-Wire controlled aircraft. Normal law is the system mode which is active throughout the flight and is terminated when system failures occur that prevent its use. The highest reduced mode of operation in Airbus FBW systems is the Alternate Law, which provides most features of normal law. Some features such as automatic stall protection are lost and replaced by conventional warnings for the pilots to manually correct the condition. This means that flight envelope protection is degraded as avionics no longer limit the pilot input to avoid stall. Should failure conditions prevent operation in Alternate Law, an even more basic Direct Law is available. Autopilot functions are lost, along with flight envelope protection. As a last emergency means of operation, Mechanical Backup is provided to maintain level flight only for the limited period of flight control computer reset following a complete loss of power. As we have stated above, a system degradation results in a loss of protection features, so the required alertness of the crew increases and leads to a higher workload.

There can be two systems powering the same surface, where one is a back-up for the other and can be used with the use of clutches on the same control run. learning.explanation: Flaps There are numerous types of flap designs which increase lift and drag in varying amounts. For light aircraft the most popular type is the plain or camber flap. For large transport aircraft the most used is the slotted Fowler flaps. (see different types in the image in the annex) In the cockpit there will be a selector where the pilot selects the desired flap setting, the input from this selector will be the input for the slat/flap control computers which control, test and monitor the operation of the flaps and slats. This computer’s output will be the input for an electrically controlled hydro-mechanical unit, a hydraulic motor, which drive the transmission which moves the flaps. The position of the flaps is measured with sensors and is indicated in the cockpit. The flaps are protected against asymmetric operation, runaway and over speed. The flap load relief system, or load limiter will retract the flaps to an intermediate position when the airspeed exceeds a predetermined speed. Once the speed has decreased below this speed, the flaps will be automatically returned to the selected flap setting. If the main hydraulic system fails, the emergency operation might be via an alternate hydraulic system or an electric motor which operates the same gear train as the normal operating system.

Thankfully, this topic is not particularly complicated so the more questions about this, the better. In a fly-by-wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the fly-by-wire control system. As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once. The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system. This is called dual input. In case that it occurs, an aural warning “DUAL INPUT” and a flashing warning light in sight of each pilot is provided. To allow one pilot to take over controls from the other, which might be necessary in case of incapacitation, etc., a red take-over button is installed on each sidestick that disables the stick on the other side when held. This button works as an autopilot disconnect when pushed once, but when it is pushed and held, it removes the other pilot's inputs from the system, and after 40 seconds of holding (A320 specific) the other pilot is "locked out" from inputs until they push their own priority button. When this condition occurs, an aural warning is provided “PRIORITY LEFT/RIGHT”, indicating the active sidestick.

content.question: On an aircraft equipped with a Fly-By-Wire control system, the pilot…

options.A: never override soft and hard protections.
options.B: can override hard protections only.
options.C: can override soft protections only.
options.D: can override soft and hard protections.

key_points: FLY-BY-WIRE (FBW) Fly-By-Wire aeroplanes function differently to conventional aeroplanes in that the pilot or autopilot input is via a flight control computer
The computer translates this input into an aircraft attitude using all three axes, which it will then maintain until another input is made
CONTROL LAWS - NORMAL LAW The Fly-By-Wire system was designed and certified to render the new generation of aircraft even more safe, cost effective, and pleasant to fly
learning.explanation: FLY-BY-WIRE (FBW) Fly-By-Wire aeroplanes function differently to conventional aeroplanes in that the pilot or autopilot input is via a flight control computer. The computer translates this input into an aircraft attitude using all three axes, which it will then maintain until another input is made. CONTROL LAWS - NORMAL LAW The Fly-By-Wire system was designed and certified to render the new generation of aircraft even more safe, cost effective, and pleasant to fly. Flight control surfaces are all : ‐ Electrically-controlled ‐ Hydraulically-actuated. Computers interpret pilot input and move the flight control surfaces, as necessary, to follow their orders. However, when in normal law, regardless of the pilot’s input, the computers will prevent excessive manoeuvres and exceedance of the safe envelope in pitch and roll axis. One of the PF's primary tasks is to maintain the aircraft within the limits of the normal flight envelope. Some circumstances, due to extreme situations or aircraft mishandling, may provoke the violation of these limits. Protections are intended to: - Provide maximum authority to the PF to consistently achieve the best possible aircraft performance in extreme conditions - Reduce the risks of over-controlling, or over-stressing the aircraft - Provide PF with an instinctive and immediate procedure to ensure that the PF achieves the best possible result. The normal law protects the aircraft throughout the flight envelope, as follows: ‐ load factor limitation ‐ pitch attitude protection ‐ high-speed protection. - bank angle protection ‐ high-angle-of-attack (AoA) protection One of the hard protections on the Airbus system, in normal law, is the stall protection. Without flight crew input, the F/CTL computers maintain the AoA equal to a defined value. The AoA can be further increased by flight crew input, up to a maximum value. The AoA will not exceed that maximum value, even if the flight crew gently pulls the sidestick all the way back. CONTROL LAWS - RECONFIGURATION LAWS Depending on the failures occurring to the flight control system, or on its peripherals, there are 3 levels of reconfiguration : ‐ Alternate law (There are two levels of alternate law : with and without reduced protections.) ‐ Direct law ‐ Mechanical ALTERNATE LAW - REDUCED PROTECTIONS - Load Factor Limitation - Pitch Attitude Protection - Low Speed Stability (Soft protection) An artificial low speed stability replaces the normal angle-of-attack protection. A gentle progressive nose down signal is introduced, that tends to keep the speed from falling below these values. The flight crew can override this demand. In addition, stall warnings are activated at an appropriate margin from the stall condition. - High Speed Stability (Soft protection) Above VMO or MMO, a nose up demand is introduced to avoid an excessive increase in speed. The flight crew can override this demand. In addition, the aural overspeed warning remains available.

content.question: You are flying an aircraft with Fly-By-Wire flight controls, operating in normal law with flight envelope protections. On short final approach, ATC instruct you to immediately go around due to a runway incursion. What should you do with the sidestick?

options.B: Pull back on the sidestick to decelerate below VFE, then reduce the back pressure and extend flaps.
options.C: Firmly pull back on the sidestick but be careful to not exceed the limit load factor.
options.D: Firmly pull back on the sidestick with no hesitation and do not worry about stalling.

key_points: Fly-By-Wire systems A Fly-By-Wire control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls
The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals
These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers
learning.explanation: Fly-By-Wire systems A Fly-By-Wire control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls. The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals. These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers. These computers provide the input for the servo valves which controls the movement of the hydraulic actuators attached to the flight control surfaces. One of the largest benefits of fly by wire is the flight envelope protection system. It has many abilities, including preventing excessive bank angles, preventing the stall, overspeed protection, overload protection, etc. In the event of a late go-around like this one, the recommended way to go around remains the same amongst all aircraft, apply TOGA thrust (or sometimes less if full TOGA thrust is not required), pitch up to a suitable go-around attitude (somewhere around 15° initially), retract flaps if necessary, and begin climbing, then "clean up" the rest of the aircraft (gain speed, gear up, retract flaps further, etc.). For that initial reaction though, Fly-By-Wire flight envelope protections could perhaps be useful. Because of the stall protection of a fly-by-wire flight control system, in theory, the pilot can just apply TO/GA thrust and pull back on the sidestick all the way, and just hold it there. The aircraft will likely go into stall protection mode, which in an Airbus A320 (as EASA usually refer to) changes the control logic slightly above αprot then applies TO/GA thrust above αfloor (the pilot should already have applied TO/GA at this point of course), so the aircraft will climb, but the system will not let the aircraft fully stall, no matter how hard the pilot pulls back. Note: This would be a very aggressive manoeuvre, and similar to terrain or windshear escape manoeuvres, which would cause the pilots far more issues later on than if they just performed a normal go-around, so this is not the way a pilot should actually fly a go-around in a fly-by-wire aircraft, it is simply a theoretical method of doing so. However, the examiner likes to find interesting ways of testing Fly-By-Wire knowledge, and that includes asking you about the very limits of the systems. Whilst pulling back on the stick with caution is quite advisable (as per one of the other options), it does not need to be gentle, particularly for a late go-around, and it is not to stop the aircraft stalling really, as the Fly-By-Wire stops that.

Which of these statements about rudder limiting are correct or incorrect?
I. A rudder ratio changer system limits both rudder and rudder pedal deflection as the IAS increases
II. A variable stop system reduces the rudder deflection for a given rudder pedal deflection as the IAS increases

learning.explanation: "I. A rudder ratio changer system limits both rudder and rudder pedal deflection as the IAS increases." Incorrect. Rudder Ratio Changer: The control commands from the rudder pedals and trim control are modified by a rudder ratio changer. As the aircraft speed inscreases, the rudder deflection must be reduced proportionately within the range of the rudder pedal depression by the pilot => the rudder peddals move through their full range at all speeds, however, rudder deflection is reduced with increasing airspeed. If this automatic reduction is not applied and rudder is fully deflected when the aircraft is in high speed flight, it will may cause the plane to sharply and violently yaw. "II. A variable stop system reduces the rudder deflection for a given rudder pedal deflection as the IAS increases." Incorrect. Variable Stop System: The movement of the rudder and pedal travel are proportional. However, as the airspeed increases, the movement of the rudder pedals and the rudder are physically reduced. When the rudder is limited in movement at high speed, the pedal travel is also restricted.

This is the system in operation during normal flights. Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight. These modes include: Ground Mode Flight Mode Flare Mode Alternate Law offers limited protection including stability, load factor and stall protections. Basically, it is the reduced mode of operation which provides most features of normal law. Direct Law is the lowest level of fly-by-wire system and directly transmits the pilot inputs to control surfaces, while still giving stall and load factor warnings Mechanical back up. In case all of the above fail, the system reverts to mechanical backup, where pitch control is achieved through the horizontal stabilizer and lateral control is accomplished using the rudder pedals. The purpose of the backup system is to allow control of the aircraft following a total loss of electrics, flight control computers, elevators, or ailerons and spoilers In case of mechanical backup, the system will operate as long as hydraulic power is available. In case of electrical failure, as long as hydraulics are OK, the pilot should be able to control the aircraft.

As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once. The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system. content.question:
Which of these statements about a gust lock system are correct or incorrect?
I. A gust lock can be used in flight to reduce the effects of turbulence
II. Reversible flight controls should have a gust lock

options.A: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.B: I is correct, II is correct.
options.C: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.D: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

key_points: "I
A gust lock can be used in flight to reduce the effects of turbulence
" Incorrect
learning.explanation: "I. A gust lock can be used in flight to reduce the effects of turbulence." Incorrect. A gust lock is essentially a device which limits the movement of a control surface while the aeroplane is parked, preventing damage when it is unattended. It stops aicraft's surfaces from being slammed back and forth in a strong wind/gusts. Typically it is the ailerons, the elevator and the rudder that are of concern. In many aircraft, the control column that supports the yoke can be immobilized in the cockpit with a heavy pin that slides through aligned holes in the column itself, thereby restarting the elevator and ailerons from moving at all. There is also a style of gust lock that attaches directly to the base of the rudder and holds it immobile. It is clearly essential that all flight control locks are removed/disengaged before flight. "II. Reversible flight controls should have a gust lock." Correct. A reversible control system is a power assisted system in which the pilot is connected directly to the controls, feeling part of the load. It is called "reversible" because if someone moves the external surfaces, the stick (or control column) and the peddals move inside the cockpit. Control surfaces move freely and in case of strong wind, for example, they may be slammed back and forth, which may cause aircraft damage. For that reason, a gust lock system should be used, inside the aircraft and/or outside.

content.question: An aeroplane extends its flaps asymmetrically. The aircraft will roll...

options.A: towards the side with fewer flaps and have a yawing moment to the same side.
options.B: towards the side with more flaps and have a yawing moment to the same side.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.02.01.07: Explain how a flap/slat asymmetry protection device functions, and describe the implications of a flap/slat asymmetry situation. A flap asymmetry situation can be disastrous. This is because flaps change the coefficient of lift of the wing massively, in order to provide more lift, and therefore allow flight at slower speeds. Flaps can easily double the coefficient of lift from a wing, whilst also increasing the drag, possibly by a lot. This means that flap asymmetry will roll the aircraft towards the cleaner wing (fewer flaps), as the wing with flaps down is producing much more lift than it. It also means that the aircraft will have asymmetric drag, and will want to yaw towards the wing with flaps down, as the flaps are causing extra drag that the clean wing is not producing. This means that the yaw is in the opposite direction from the roll.

Fly-By-Wire is the control system that connects the pilots inputs to the aircraft control surfaces via computers, giving no direct physical connection, but providing benefits such as flight envelope protection and reduced weight of control systems. Flight envelope protection is what is being discussed in this question. An aircraft with fly-by-wire operating in normal law will have a full suite of stall protections. These mean that the system will not let the pilot stall the aircraft by pulling back too hard or too far with the sidestick. It also protects the aircraft from pulling more than the limit load factor. This means that during a terrain escape manoeuvre, when the aim is to gain as much altitude as possible in the shortest distance, the pilot can just pull back on the sidestick to full deflection, and the fly-by-wire system will ensure a controlled pitch up to a high (but safe) pitch angle, allowing the speed to reduce to the point where the aircraft reaches "max alpha", and then the aircraft will pitch down to maintain that angle of attack. Whether this is an approved way of performing a terrain escape manoeuvre is irrelevant to the question, which is simply testing your technical knowledge of fly-by-wire systems.

content.question:
Which of the following are used to limit rudder deflection?
1. Gust lock
2. Variable stops
3. Ratio changer
4. Control locks
5. Blow-back

options.A: 1, 2 and 4
options.B: 2, 3 and 5
options.C: 2, 4 and 5
options.D: 3, 4 and 5

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.01.05.05: Explain the concept of a rudder deflection limitation (rudder limiter) system and the various means of implementation (rudder ratio changer, variable stops, blow-back). As stated in the Learning Objective above, there are 3 ways to limit rudder deflection, which we want to do at higher airspeeds to limit the forces on the aircraft: Rudder Ratio Changer: The control commands from the rudder pedals and trim control are modified by a rudder ratio changer. As the aircraft speed increases, the rudder deflection must be reduced proportionately within the range of the rudder pedal depression by the pilot => the rudder pedals move through their full range at all speeds, however, rudder deflection is reduced with increasing airspeed. If this automatic reduction is not applied and rudder is fully deflected when the aircraft is in high speed flight, the huge forces could damage the aircraft, or at least cause violent yaw/roll. Variable Stops: The movement of the rudder and the pedal travel are directly proportional to each other. However, as the airspeed increases, the movement of the rudder pedals and the rudder are physically reduced. When the rudder is limited in movement at high speed, the pedal travel is also restricted. This does have the consequence of making the rudder very sensitive at high airspeeds, just not with a very long pedal travel. Blow-Back: This is a system that applies a constant movement force to the rudder, the force being dictated by the pedal deflection, which then deflects the rudder depending on the speed of the airflow. slower airspeed means that the constant force will deflect the rudder more, whereas fast airspeed would mean the consequent higher dynamic pressure naturally limits the rudder deflection, acting like a more modern rudder ratio changer.

content.question: Extension of the wing spoilers is often limited to a maximum airspeed. What is the reason for this?

options.A: To prevent roll control problems at high speed.
options.B: To prevent longitudinal instability at high speed.
options.C: To prevent structural damage to the spoilers at excessive dynamic pressures.
options.D: To ensure maximum fuel efficiency by braking at the highest possible speed.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.02.01.05: Describe the requirement for limiting flight speeds for the various secondary flight control surfaces. Secondary flight controls such as flaps, slats, and spoilers often contain maximum speed limits for their use, due to the fact that they stick into the airflow, which will exert significant force on them due to dynamic pressure. The dynamic pressure exerted is proportional to the square of the air velocity, so for a doubling of speed, the dynamic pressure increases by x4. If the secondary flight controls were extended past their maximum speed, the devices and the mechanisms keeping them in place could be overpowered or may be permanently damaged. For spoilers, they are subject to huge amounts of dynamic pressure as part of their job "spoiling" the airflow over the wing, so are particularly susceptible to this. Note: The spoilers/speedbrakes on an aircraft wing are usually secondary flight controls, but when roll spoilers are active, the roll spoilers are actually classed as primary flight controls because they are acting as ailerons.

learning.explanation: TRIM RUNAWAY While the use of an electrical trim system can provide important safety and convenience benefits, it can also introduce the potential for a malfunction called “Trim Runaway.” Trim Runaway occurs when the Trimmable Horizontal Stabilizer (THS) or other trim device on the aircraft tail fails to stop at the desired position and continues to deflect up or down. A full stabilizer deflection could prevent the aircraft from returning to a safe landing. A Runaway Pitch Trim can be fatal in flight because it would run the horizontal stabilizer either up or down to its mechanical stops, and the use of the elevators would not be sufficient to overcome this force. In most Electrical Trim systems, two toggle switches are required for a stabilizer trim system, where one of them releases the trim brake and the other one drives the motor. You must use both to activate the stabilizer trim - they are designed in such a way on the control column that if you trim, you will always push them together. The reason you need double trim switches is primarily to prevent Trim Runaway on the stabilizer, if one switch runs away then the other can be used to stop it.

options.A: fixing both control columns to each other so that increased force can be exerted by both pilots for manual reversion.
options.B: multiple flight control computers linked to multiple actuators supplied by different power sources.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.01.05.02: Explain how redundancy is obtained in primary flight control systems of large transport aeroplanes. Modern transport aircraft must be equipped with safeguards to prevent loss of control in the event of hydraulic or electrical failure. This is typically achieved by incorporating redundancy into the control system. One common method of redundancy is splitting control surfaces into two or three sections, each powered by separate actuators and hydraulic systems. In addition, computer system redundancy is also provided in some modern transport aircraft, such as Airbus aircraft. In a large transport aircraft with fully powered primary flight controls, redundancy can be achieved by having multiple flight control computers linked to multiple actuators supplied by different power sources. This configuration ensures that, in the event of a single-point failure, the aircraft's control surfaces remain operable and the pilots can continue to control the aircraft safely.

content.question:
Which of these statements are correct, as regards trimming in an irreversible flight control system of a conventional aeroplane equipped with a trimmable horizontal stabiliser?
1. The zero force position of the control column does not change when using the pitch trim
2. The zero force position of the control wheel does not change when using the aileron trim

options.A: Both 1 and 2 are correct.
options.B: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.C: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.D: Both 1 and 2 are incorrect.

key_points: Statement 1: The zero force position of the control column does not change when using the pitch trim
CORRECT: The zero force position will not change when using pitch (elevator) trim Statement 2: The zero force position of the control wheel does not change when using the aileron trim
INCORRECT: The zero force position will change when using the aileron trim
learning.explanation: Statement 1: The zero force position of the control column does not change when using the pitch trim. CORRECT: The zero force position will not change when using pitch (elevator) trim Statement 2: The zero force position of the control wheel does not change when using the aileron trim. INCORRECT: The zero force position will change when using the aileron trim. Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude. The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls. The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible. This means that a force applied to the controls is a force which moves the control surface, and also a force which moves the control surface will move the pilot’s controls. This means that the air pressure on the control surface can be felt in the pilot’s controls. When the flight controls are fully power operated this is not the case and is called irreversible. This means that if there is a force moving the control surface this will not move the control columns, and there will be no natural feel on the controls. Because of this there will need to be an artificial feel unit installed in a fully powered or irreversible control system. This artificial feel unit should apply force to the cockpit controls in proportion to the control deflection and in proportion to the aircraft’s speed. This artificial feel system will also work with a trim system, but this works different than a normal trim surface does. In the figure in the annex you can see how the trim of the artificial feel unit works. A movement of the trimwheel will result in a movement of the electric trim actuator, and so the control surface, but not in the movement of the control column (this is for elevator control). It is different for aileron and rudder trim. Elevator trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim)

For large transport aircraft the most used is the slotted Fowler flaps. (see different types in the image in the annex) In the cockpit there will be a selector where the pilot selects the desired flap setting, the input from this selector will be the input for the slat/flap control computers which control, test and monitor the operation of the flaps and slats. This computer’s output will be the input for an electrically controlled hydro-mechanical unit, a hydraulic motor, which drive the transmission which moves the flaps.
