Once the speed has decreased below this speed, the flaps will be automatically returned to the selected flap setting. content.question: A Fly-By-Wire (FBW) system has different modes of operation. Of the modes listed below, which one is the most basic?

options.A: Direct mode
options.B: Direct computer mode
options.C: Alternate mode
options.D: Secondary mode

key_points: Boeing and Airbus call these a bit different but the principle stays the same
Airbus has the following laws: Normal law Flight control Normal Law provides three axis control, flight envelope protection and manoeuver load alleviation
Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight
learning.explanation: Boeing and Airbus call these a bit different but the principle stays the same. Airbus has the following laws: Normal law Flight control Normal Law provides three axis control, flight envelope protection and manoeuver load alleviation. Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight. These modes include: Ground Mode, Flight Mode, Flare Mode Alternate law Alternate Law 1 (ALT1) combines Normal Law lateral mode with Alternate Law pitch modes. Low Energy Protection is replaced by Low Speed Stability meaning that the aircraft no longer has automatic stall protection. At low speed, a nose down demand is introduced based on IAS (instead of AOA) and Alternate Law changes to Direct Law. In addition, an audio "STALL" warning is introduced. α-Floor protection is not available so conventional pilot stall recovery action is required. Load Factor and Bank Angle Protections are retained. High Speed and High Angle of Attack Protections enter Alternate Law mode. Pitch Attitude Protection is lost. ALT1 control law degradation will result from some faults in the horizontal stabilizer, a single elevator fault, loss of a yaw-damper actuator, loss of slat or flap position sensors or a single air data reference fault. Dependent upon the failure, autopilot may not be available. In Alternate Law 2 (ALT2), Normal Law lateral mode is lost and is replaced by roll Direct Law and yaw Alternate Law. Pitch mode is in Alternate Law. Load factor protection is retained. In addition to those protections lost in ALT1 (Pitch Attitude and Low Energy Protection), Bank Angle Protection is also lost. In some failure cases, High Angle of Attack and High Speed Protections will also be lost. As is the case with ALT1, some failure cases that result in ALT2 will also cause the autopilot to disconnect. ALT2 is entered when both engines flame out, with faults in two inertial or two air-data reference units, with faults to all spoilers, certain aileron faults or with a pedal transducers fault Direct law In Direct Law (DIR), lateral modes are the same as ALT2; that is roll Direct Law and yaw Alternate Law. Pitch control degrades to Direct Law and automatic trim is inoperative requiring stab trim to be adjusted manually by the pilot. Control surface motion is directly related to the sidestick motion. ALL protections are lost. In Direct Law, autopilot function is always lost. DIR is entered if there is failure of all three inertial reference units or all three primary flight computers, faults in both elevators or flame out of both engines concurrent with loss of PRIM 1. Boeing uses: Normal mode In Normal mode during manual flight, the ACEs receive pilot control inputs and send these signals to the three PFCs. The PFCs verify these signals and utilise information from other airplane systems in order to compute control surface commands. These commands are then sent back to the ACEs which then send the enhanced signals to the flight control surface actuators which convert them into analog servo commands. Full functionality is provided including all enhanced performance, envelope protection and ride quality features. When the autopilot is engaged, the autopilot system sends commands to the PFCs. The PFCs generate control surface commands which are sent to the ACEs in the same manner as pilot control inputs. The autopilot commands move the flight deck controls to provide autopilot feedback to the pilots. If a pilot overrides the autopilot with control inputs, the PFCs will disengage the autopilot and utilise the pilot control inputs. Note that the autopilot is not available should reversion to Secondary or Direct mode occur. Secondary mode Boeing Secondary mode is somewhat similar to the Airbus Alternate Law. When the PFCs cannot support Normal mode operation due to internal faults or to loss of information from other aircraft systems, they automatically revert to Secondary mode. Reversion to Secondary mode results in the loss of the autopilot and the pilots must control the aircraft manually. The ACEs still receive pilot control inputs and send the appropriate signals to the PFCs. However, due to the degraded mode of operation, the PFCs use "simplified" computations to generate the flight control surface commands. These commands are sent back to the ACEs from where they are sent to the flight control surfaces in the same manner as during Normal mode operations. Aircraft handling qualities are affected by the simplified computations or PFC control laws that are utilised in Secondary mode. While all flight control surfaces remain operative, the elevator and rudder are more sensitive at some airspeeds. The following functions are inoperative or degraded during Secondary mode operations: autopilot auto speedbrakes envelope protection gust suppression tail strike protection thrust asymmetry compensation yaw damping Direct mode The ACEs automatically revert to Direct mode when they detect the failure of all three PFCs or when they are unable to communicate with the PFCs. Direct mode can also be manually selected by selecting the DISC position on the Primary Flight Computers Disconnect switch. In Direct mode, the PFCs no longer generate control surface commands. Pilot inputs are received by the ACEs and sent directly to the flight control surface actuators. Direct mode allows for full aircraft control while in flight and during the landing phase. Aircraft handling characteristics are very similar to those encountered while in Secondary mode. In addition to those functions lost during Secondary mode operations (as listed previously) the manual rudder trim cancel switch is inoperative.

content.question: A Fly-By-Wire system is always irreversible because…

options.A: there is a mechanical linkage between the flight control surfaces and the pilot controls. The pilot inputs move the control surfaces directly.
options.B: linked mechanically to a computer and then to the flight control surface.

key_points: In a Fly-By-Wire system, the pilot inputs are transmitted to the flight control surfaces through a computer, which then actuates the hydraulic or electrical systems that move the control surfaces
This means that the pilot inputs do not directly move the control surfaces, and any corrective action must be taken through the computer system

learning.explanation: In a Fly-By-Wire system, the pilot inputs are transmitted to the flight control surfaces through a computer, which then actuates the hydraulic or electrical systems that move the control surfaces. This means that the pilot inputs do not directly move the control surfaces, and any corrective action must be taken through the computer system. This means that FBW is irreversible as there will be no direct feedback from aerodynamic forces on the control surfaces without an artificial feel system. This design feature allows for the implementation of various flight control laws and protections that can enhance the safety and performance of the aircraft. However, it also means that the system is irreversible, as the pilot cannot directly override the computer's commands to the flight control surfaces. Therefore, in a Fly-By-Wire system, the control surfaces are moved indirectly by the pilot inputs via a computer, which makes the system irreversible. Option "the link between the pilot inputs and control surfaces is via a computer, so the control surfaces are moved indirectly by the pilot inputs" correctly explains this concept.

key_points: Fly-By-Wire flight controls offer many benefits to an aircraft, one of the largest being the addition of flight envelope protection
Provided the FBW system functions at its normal level, this significantly enhances safety

learning.explanation: Fly-By-Wire flight controls offer many benefits to an aircraft, one of the largest being the addition of flight envelope protection. Provided the FBW system functions at its normal level, this significantly enhances safety. Feedback control of airspeed, Mach Number, attitude, and angle of attack can be used to ensure that the FBW aircraft stays within its certificated flight envelope. At high angles of attack/low airspeeds, sometimes called high alpha, Fly-By-Wire systems have certain protections to prevent the aircraft stalling. key_points: As you can see at the bottom of this explanation, for the aileron and rudder the “zero force point” will be adjusted when trimming
This is not the case for elevator trim

learning.explanation: As you can see at the bottom of this explanation, for the aileron and rudder the “zero force point” will be adjusted when trimming. This is not the case for elevator trim. Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude. The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls. The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible. This means that a force applied to the controls is a force which moves the control surface, and also a force which moves the control surface will move the pilot’s controls. This means that the air pressure on the control surface can be felt in the pilot’s controls. When the flight controls are fully power operated this is not the case and is called irreversible. This means that if there is a force moving the control surface this will not move the control columns, and there will be no natural feel on the controls. Because of this there will need to be an artificial feel unit installed in a fully powered or irreversible control system. This artificial feel unit should apply force to the cockpit controls in proportion to the control deflection and in proportion to the aircraft’s speed. The artificial feel system is placed in parallel with the hydraulic actuator, so the movement of the flight controls in the cockpit will cause the hydraulic actuator to operate. During this same movement the artificial feel system will apply pressure on the controls appropriate to the airspeed of the aircraft. This artificial feel system will also work with a trim system, but this works different than a normal trim surface does. A movement of the trimwheel will result in a movement of the electric trim actuator, and so the control surface, but not in the movement of the control column (this is for elevator control). It is different for aileron and rudder trim. Elevator trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim)

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.02.01.07: Explain how a flap/slat asymmetry protection device functions, and describe the implications of a flap/slat asymmetry situation. A flap asymmetry situation can be disastrous. This is because flaps change the coefficient of lift of the wing massively, in order to provide more lift, and therefore allow flight at slower speeds. Flaps can easily double the coefficient of lift from a wing, whilst also increasing the drag, possibly by a lot. An aircraft will fly terribly with even a medium sized flap asymmetry, with high drag and high lift on one wing but not the other. A way to avoid this situation is by having a flap/slat asymmetry protection system. This detects the actual flap/slat position in each wing with great accuracy, and as soon as an asymmetry is detected, the system will stop the flaps/slats from moving, and show up a warning or caution to the pilots.

learning.explanation: FLY-BY-WIRE In a fly-by-wire aircraft, the pilot inputs commands via a sidestick or yoke to a computer. The computer then processes these inputs and sends corresponding electrical signals to the the servo valve which in turn controls the movement of a hydraulic actuator, which will hydraulically deflect a flight control surface. There are numerous advantages to FBW systems, including weight savings and safety features that can be incorporated into the computer software. FBW also enables highly reliable flight envelope protection systems which, provided the FBW system functions at its normal level, significantly enhances safety. Feedback control of airspeed, Mach Number, attitude, and angle of attack can be used to ensure that the FBW aircraft stays within its certificated flight envelope. For instance, on the Airbus, the flight mode of Normal Law provides five types of protection: pitch attitude, load factor limitations, high speed, high-AoA and bank angle. In addition, Low Speed Protection is available in certain phases of flight. The bank angle protection system on a FBW aircraft has the ability to change the control inputs to keep the aircraft within its safe flight envelope, and can therefore make it harder to maintain a bank angle that is outside of limits. The system would not override the pilot too much, and in dire situations the pilot may require high bank angles, which would still be possible in a FBW aircraft, as not to degrade safety.

Airbus uses: Normal Law Alternate Law Direct Law Boeing uses: Normal Mode Secondary Mode Direct Mode A quick run-down of the control laws (primarily Airbus, but these small descriptions fit Boeing's modes well). Normal Law - All control augmentations and protections are in place. Alternate Law - Some protections are lost, some features act differently from normal, and the autopilot may be lost (depending on the fault). key_points: There are 4 main types of control system: Manual - cables and pulleys connect the flight controls to the control surfaces directly

learning.explanation: There are 4 main types of control system: Manual - cables and pulleys connect the flight controls to the control surfaces directly. The only power supplied is by the pilot. Partially powered/Power assisted controls - The pilot is mechanically connected to the controls, but any force they exert will be assisted by extra force from the hydraulics. Similar to powered steering in a car. Fully powered controls - The flight controls physically move a servo valve which directs hydraulic pressure to the controls. No computers involved, but hydraulic pressure is absolutely required. Fly-By-Wire - A type of fully powered control system where the flight control movements are interpreted by a computer which electronically controls the hydraulic servo valves to move the control surfaces. The hydraulics still provide the power to move the control surfaces, but a computer sits between the pilot and the hydraulics, checking and modifying the requested movements. Fly-by-wire and fully powered controls are "irreversible", meaning that there is no feedback from the control surfaces to the pilot. This means that an artificial feel system has to be installed, so the pilot can feel the correct amount of resistance when moving the controls. This is not the case on manual or power assisted control systems, which are "reversible", and have natural feedback to the flight controls. Power assisted controls do not have as much feedback as manual controls of course, as the hydraulic system takes most of the force, but the pilot will feel a certain percentage of it, and the feel force does come from the actual aerodynamic forces acting on the control surface.

learning.explanation: When EASA mention a Fly-By-Wire aircraft with sidesticks, they usually mean the Airbus A320. When an aircraft is fitted with sidesticks for manual control, these sidesticks are connected digitally to the FBW (Fly-By-Wire) system to provide input for aileron and elevator control. The sidestick on each side of the flight deck feature a red button, used for autopilot disconnect, or as a "priority takeover" button. Priority takeover is added as the sidesticks are not mechanically linked so the pilots must be able to decide who is controlling the aircraft manually, as dual inputs can otherwise occur. to disconnect the autopilot when engaged in "command" (i.e. the aircraft is automatically flying), this red button can be pushed, the autopilot can be de-selected on the control panel (the flight-deck glareshield panel), or the pilot can simply make a large enough input on the sidestick, which will also disengage the autopilot and allow the pilot to control the aircraft manually. The pilot cannot and must not disconnect the FBW system entirely, as this would leave the aircraft with no elevator or aileron control, and very limited mechanical reversion control.

key_points: Flight spoilers Flight spoilers are fitted on the upper side of the surface of the wing which can be raised

When a flight spoiler is raised it disturbs the flow over the wing causing a decrease in lift
learning.explanation: Flight spoilers Flight spoilers are fitted on the upper side of the surface of the wing which can be raised. They may be used to give directional control together, or instead of the ailerons. When a flight spoiler is raised it disturbs the flow over the wing causing a decrease in lift. When the flight spoilers are used for lateral control, on the wing that is meant to go down, the spoilers will extend while the spoilers on the up going wing remain retracted. Unlike ailerons, spoilers will not increase lift and so the use of spoilers instead of ailerons will cause a decrease in lift, this however will give some advantages over ailerons. As the raised spoiler will increase drag, the yaw directions will be in the same direction as the roll, therefore there will be no adverse yaw. When flying at transonic speeds there will be no shock induced, so the effectiveness stays the same. Because the spoilers are not located at the end of the wings there will be less wing twisting because the loss of lift will be distributed more even across the wingchord. Flight spoilers can also be used as speedbrakes, these can be used either in the air or on the ground. When on the ground the spoilers will be extended further than when in the air. key_points: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the fly-by-wire control system

learning.explanation: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the fly-by-wire control system. As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once. The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system. This is called dual input. In case that it occurs, an aural warning “DUAL INPUT” and a flashing warning light in sight of each pilot is provided. To allow one pilot to take over controls from the other, which might be necessary in case of incapacitation, etc., a red take-over button is installed on each sidestick that disables the stick on the other side when held. This button works as an autopilot disconnect when pushed once, but when it is pushed and held, it removes the other pilot's inputs from the system, and after 40 seconds of holding (A320 specific) the other pilot is "locked out" from inputs until they push their own priority button. When this condition occurs, an aural warning is provided “PRIORITY LEFT/RIGHT”, indicating the active sidestick.

content.question: An aircraft is powered down, and the rudder is at full left deflection, but the rudder pedals are centred. What can we say about the aircraft's control system?

options.A: Irreversible controls.
options.B: Reversible controls.
options.C: Power assisted controls.
options.D: Any type of control system could be used since the rudder position and pedal position are independent of each other after shutdown.

key_points: There are two basic types of flight controls, reversible and irreversible
Reversible flight controls are those that have a two way force mechanism naturally as part of the system

This includes manual flight controls, which use levers and pulleys to transfer pilot force to the controls, and partially powered controls, which are aided by hydraulic force, but there is still a mechanical connection between the pilot and controls (think powered steering in a car)
learning.explanation: There are two basic types of flight controls, reversible and irreversible. Reversible flight controls are those that have a two way force mechanism naturally as part of the system. This includes manual flight controls, which use levers and pulleys to transfer pilot force to the controls, and partially powered controls, which are aided by hydraulic force, but there is still a mechanical connection between the pilot and controls (think powered steering in a car). The connecting factor means that if you went to the aileron and pushed it, the controls in the cockpit would move accordingly. The opposite are irreversible controls, which have no "backwards force", or "feel". These are only 1 way, so the pilot can move the control surfaces, but the control surfaces cannot move the pilot's controls. Fully powered hydraulic controls and Fly-By-Wire controls are irreversible. Irreversible controls have no natural feedback, so require artificial "feel", so the pilot has something to push against and the controls naturally centre, etc. If you pushed the aileron, the controls would not move. Therefore, in this scenario, there is no connection at all between the control surfaces and the cockpit controls (especially as the aircraft is powered down, so there is no automatic control centring, etc.). Therefore, if the rudder goes to full deflection by the wind or by someone pushing it, etc., there would be no corresponding movement of the rudder pedals. That would be the case for any irreversible control system, but the rudder pedals would also move if the system were reversible.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.02.01.07: Explain how a flap/slat asymmetry protection device functions, and describe the implications of a flap/slat asymmetry situation. A flap asymmetry situation can be disastrous. This is because flaps change the coefficient of lift of the wing massively, in order to provide more lift, and therefore allow flight at slower speeds. Flaps can easily double the coefficient of lift from a wing, whilst also increasing the drag, possibly by a lot. An aircraft will fly terribly with a large flap asymmetry, with high drag and high lift on one wing but not the other. A way to avoid this situation is by having a flap/slat asymmetry protection system. This detects the actual flap/slat position in each wing with great accuracy, and as soon as an asymmetry is detected, the system will stop the flaps from moving, and show up a warning or caution to the pilots.

key_points: FLY-BY-WIRE In a fly-by-wire aircraft, the pilot inputs commands via a sidestick or yoke to a computer

The computer then processes these inputs and sends corresponding electrical signals to the the servo valve which in turn controls the movement of a hydraulic actuator, which will hydraulically deflect a flight control surface. There are numerous advantages to fly by wire systems, including weight savings and safety features that can be incorporated into the computer software. FBW also enables highly reliable flight envelope protection systems which, provided the FBW system functions at its normal level, significantly enhances safety. Feedback control of airspeed, Mach Number, attitude, and angle of attack can be used to ensure that the FBW aircraft stays within its certificated flight envelope. For instance, on the Airbus, the flight mode of Normal Law provides five types of protection: pitch attitude, load factor limitations, high speed, high-AOA and bank angle. key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.01.05.05: Explain the concept of a rudder deflection limitation (rudder limiter) system and the various means of implementation (rudder ratio changer, variable stops, blow-back). As stated in the Learning Objective above, there are 3 ways to limit rudder deflection, which we want to do at higher airspeeds to limit the forces on the aircraft: Rudder Ratio Changer: The control commands from the rudder pedals and trim control are modified by a rudder ratio changer. As the aircraft speed increases, the rudder deflection must be reduced proportionately within the range of the rudder pedal depression by the pilot => the rudder pedals move through their full range at all speeds, however, rudder deflection is reduced with increasing airspeed. If this automatic reduction is not applied and rudder is fully deflected when the aircraft is in high speed flight, the huge forces could damage the aircraft, or at least cause violent yaw/roll. Variable Stops: The movement of the rudder and the pedal travel are directly proportional to each other. However, as the airspeed increases, the movement of the rudder pedals and the rudder are physically reduced. When the rudder is limited in movement at high speed, the pedal travel is also restricted. This does have the consequence of making the rudder very sensitive at high airspeeds, just not with a very long pedal travel. The figure above shows the allowed deflection of a particular aircraft. Blow-Back: This is a system that applies a constant movement force to the rudder, the force being dictated by the pedal deflection, which then deflects the rudder depending on the speed of the airflow. slower airspeed means that the constant force will deflect the rudder more, whereas fast airspeed would mean the consequent higher dynamic pressure naturally limits the rudder deflection, acting like a more modern rudder ratio changer. The reason that statement 2 is incorrect is that it says the limitations to rudder/rudder pedal deflection occur with decreasing airspeed, but actually it is with increasing airspeed.

key_points: FLY-BY-WIRE (FBW) (figure 1) A fly by wire system is a powered flying control system that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid operated servo valve rather than the mechanical inputs on conventional power controls

The pilot operates the flight deck controls, which in turn operates transducers which convert the mechanical input into an electrical output which is amplified, processed by computers with the processed command signal providing the input to the servo valve which controls the movement of a hydraulic actuator
The A320 is a typical example of an aircraft with a FBW system in which all surfaces are actuated hydraulically and are electrically or mechanically controlled
learning.explanation: FLY-BY-WIRE (FBW) (figure 1) A fly by wire system is a powered flying control system that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid operated servo valve rather than the mechanical inputs on conventional power controls. The pilot operates the flight deck controls, which in turn operates transducers which convert the mechanical input into an electrical output which is amplified, processed by computers with the processed command signal providing the input to the servo valve which controls the movement of a hydraulic actuator. The A320 is a typical example of an aircraft with a FBW system in which all surfaces are actuated hydraulically and are electrically or mechanically controlled. SYSTEM REDUNDANCY (figure 2) Safeguards to eliminate the possibility of loss of control in the event of hydraulic or electrical failure must be provided on modern transport aircraft. This is generally achieved by building some form of redundancy into the control system. Splitting the control surfaces into two or three sections, each powered by separate actuators and hydraulic systems is the usual method. The A320 (EASA's usual favourite aircraft) has 2 actuators per aileron aswell, an active and a "damping", which can be used in the event of the failure of the active. content.question:
What are the advantages of Fly-By-Wire control?
1. Reduction of the electric and hydraulic power required to operate the control surfaces
2. Lesser sensitivity to lightning strike
3. Direct and indirect weight saving through simplification of systems
4. Immunity to different interfering signals
5. Improvement of piloting quality throughout the flight envelope

key_points: A Fly-By-Wire (FBW) system represents an advanced method of controlling aircraft flight, where electronic signals replace traditional mechanical inputs
Instead of direct manipulation of physical controls, such as conventional control columns and rudder pedals, pilots interface with flight deck controls like side sticks (as seen in Airbus aircraft)
These inputs are then translated into electrical signals by transducers, which are further enhanced and processed by onboard computers
learning.explanation: A Fly-By-Wire (FBW) system represents an advanced method of controlling aircraft flight, where electronic signals replace traditional mechanical inputs. Instead of direct manipulation of physical controls, such as conventional control columns and rudder pedals, pilots interface with flight deck controls like side sticks (as seen in Airbus aircraft). These inputs are then translated into electrical signals by transducers, which are further enhanced and processed by onboard computers. The processed commands are then transmitted to a servo valve, which, in turn, regulates the movement of a hydraulic actuator, ultimately controlling the aircraft's flight surfaces. FBW systems can be lighter than a conventional system as FBW does not require the heavy control cables. Including FBW provides a significant reduction in fuel consumption. The FBW systems also provide flight envelope protection by preventing the pilot pitching the aircraft beyond the stalling angle of attack. It will also allow the pilot to operate the controls positively up to the 2.5g limit without fear of overstressing the aircraft.

content.question: Which mode is the most demanding for the pilots (most workload)?

options.B: Alternate Law
options.C: Direct Law
options.D: Direct computer mode

key_points: The Fly-By-Wire system has multiple redundancies that offer layered protection: Normal Law offers all the protections (like stall, load factor etc)
This is the system in operation during normal flights
Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight
learning.explanation: The Fly-By-Wire system has multiple redundancies that offer layered protection: Normal Law offers all the protections (like stall, load factor etc). This is the system in operation during normal flights. Normal Law operates in different modes depending on the stage of flight. These modes include: Ground Mode Flight Mode Flare Mode Alternate Law offers limited protection including stability, load factor and stall protections. Basically, it is the reduced mode of operation which provides most features of normal law. Direct Law is the lowest level of fly-by-wire system and directly transmits the pilot inputs to control surfaces, while still giving stall and load factor warnings. In Direct Law, autopilot function is always lost. Mechanical back up. In case all of the above fail, the system reverts to mechanical backup, where pitch control is achieved through the horizontal stabilizer and lateral control is accomplished using the rudder pedals. The purpose of the backup system is to allow control of the aircraft following a total loss of electrics, flight control computers, elevators, or ailerons and spoilers In case of mechanical backup, the system will operate as long as hydraulic power is available. In case of electrical failure, as long as hydraulics are OK, the pilot should be able to control the aircraft.

learning.explanation: Since flaps significantly change the aerodynamic characteristics of the wing both by increased lift and increased drag, abnormal asymmetric operation of the augmentation device could seriously jeopardise flight safety by asymmetrically loading the wings. If the situation is allowed to progress unchecked, it will result in a pronounced roll towards the wing with the lessor amount of flap extended. In this case, it is possible that the induced roll could exceed the amount of aileron authority available and could result in a spin or other loss of control situation. In all cases of asymmetric flap, the wing with the greater amount of flap extended is producing a substantially higher amount of lift. At the same time, increased drag on the flaps-down side creates a pronounced adverse yaw situation, with the nose swinging toward the wing with most flaps deflected.

Fly-By-Wire flight controls offer many benefits to an aircraft, one of the largest being the addition of flight envelope protection. Provided the FBW system functions at its normal level, this significantly enhances safety. Feedback control of airspeed, Mach Number, attitude, and angle of attack can be used to ensure that the FBW aircraft stays within its certificated flight envelope. For instance, on the Airbus, the flight mode of Normal Law provides five types of protection: pitch attitude, load factor limitations, overspeed, high-AoA/low airspeed and bank angle. At high angles of attack/low airspeeds, sometimes called high alpha, Fly-By-Wire systems have certain protections to prevent the aircraft stalling. Take Airbus for instance, their aircraft have alpha prot., alpha floor, and alpha max. Each level increases the amount of protections, from automatically beginning a descent to remain at a safe speed (alpha prot.) all the way up to alpha max, which the pilots cannot physically exceed (whilst in normal law). These protections reduce pilot workload, by allowing the pilots to think about things other than flying the aircraft near the stall. content.question: Consider a partially powered flight control system. Which of the following statements is true?

options.A: It automatically adjusts the flight controls without pilot input to maintain the flight path.
options.B: It allows the pilot to feel the aerodynamic load on the flight controls.
options.C: It completely isolates the pilot from feeling any feedback through the flight controls.
options.D: It uses electronic signals and computers to translate pilot inputs into control surface movement, with no mechanical connection.

key_points: There are 4 main types of control system: Manual - cables and pulleys connect the flight controls to the control surfaces directly
The only power supplied is by the pilot
Partially powered/Power assisted controls - The pilot is mechanically connected to the controls, but any force they exert will be assisted by extra force from the hydraulics
learning.explanation: There are 4 main types of control system: Manual - cables and pulleys connect the flight controls to the control surfaces directly. The only power supplied is by the pilot. Partially powered/Power assisted controls - The pilot is mechanically connected to the controls, but any force they exert will be assisted by extra force from the hydraulics. Similar to powered steering in a car. Fully powered controls - The flight controls physically move a servo valve which directs hydraulic pressure to the controls. No computers involved, but hydraulic pressure is absolutely required. Fly-by-wire - A type of fully powered control system where the flight control movements are interpreted by a computer which electronically controls the hydraulic servo valves to move the control surfaces. The hydraulics still provide the power to move the control surfaces, but a computer sits between the pilot and the hydraulics, checking and modifying the requested movements. Fly-by-wire and fully powered controls are "irreversible", meaning that there is no feedback from the control surfaces to the pilot. This means that an artificial feel system has to be installed, so the pilot can feel the correct amount of resistance when moving the controls. This is not the case on manual or power assisted (partially powered) control systems, which are "reversible", and have natural feedback to the flight controls. Power assisted controls do not have as much feedback as manual controls of course, as the hydraulic system takes most of the force, but the pilot will feel a certain percentage of it, and the feel force does come from the actual aerodynamic forces acting on the control surface.

content.question: What is the basic principle of a fully manual flight control system?

options.A: The flight control surfaces are connected to the flight deck controls by means of mechanical links only.
options.B: The deflection angle of the flight control surface will vary with airspeed, therefore, the flight control forces are constant.
options.C: A fully manual flight control system is an irreversible system because there is no flight deck flight control feedback when a flight control surface is in motion.
options.D: A fully manual flight control system is manually operated by the pilot by means of the flight control elements and is powered by a hydraulic system.

key_points: A fully manual flight control system would be a reversible control system, meaning the forces applied on the controls are the forces moving the control surfaces and vice versa
This are connected by mechanical links only and aren’t powered in any way
Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude
learning.explanation: A fully manual flight control system would be a reversible control system, meaning the forces applied on the controls are the forces moving the control surfaces and vice versa. This are connected by mechanical links only and aren’t powered in any way. Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude. The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls. The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible. This means that a force applied to the controls is a force which moves the control surface, and also a force which moves the control surface will move the pilot’s controls. This means that the air pressure on the control surface can be felt in the pilot’s controls. When the flight controls are fully power operated this is not the case and is called irreversible. This means that if there is a force moving the control surface this will not move the control columns, and there will be no natural feel on the controls. Because of this there will need to be an artificial feel unit installed in a fully powered or irreversible control system. This artificial feel unit should apply force to the cockpit controls in proportion to the control deflection and in proportion to the aircraft’s speed. This artificial feel system will also work with a trim system, but this works different than a normal trim surface does. In the figure in the annex you can see how the trim of the artificial feel unit works. A movement of the trimwheel will result in a movement of the electric trim actuator, and so the control surface, but not in the movement of the control column (this is for elevator control). It is different for aileron and rudder trim. Elevator trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim)

content.question: A large transport aircraft is fitted with flight spoilers, speed brakes, trailing-edge flaps, and a moveable horizontal stabiliser. If this aircraft’s ailerons are jammed, roll control may be achieved by using the…

options.B: speed brakes.
options.C: flight spoilers.

key_points: Flight spoilers Flight spoilers are fitted on the upper side of the surface of the wing which can be raised
They may be used to give directional control together, or instead of the ailerons
When a flight spoiler is raised it disturbs the flow over the wing causing a decrease in lift
learning.explanation: Flight spoilers Flight spoilers are fitted on the upper side of the surface of the wing which can be raised. They may be used to give directional control together, or instead of the ailerons. When a flight spoiler is raised it disturbs the flow over the wing causing a decrease in lift. When the flight spoilers are used for lateral control, on the wing that is meant to go down, the spoilers will extend while the spoilers on the up going wing remain retracted. Unlike ailerons, spoilers will not increase lift and so the use of spoilers instead of ailerons will cause a decrease in lift, this however will give some advantages over ailerons. As the raised spoiler will increase drag, the yaw directions will be in the same direction as the roll, therefore there will be no adverse yaw. When flying at transonic speeds there will be no shock induced, so the effectiveness stays the same. Because the spoilers are not located at the end of the wings there will be less wing twisting because the loss of lift will be distributed more even across the wingchord. Flight spoilers can also be used as speedbrakes, these can be used either in the air or on the ground. When on the ground the spoilers will be extended further than when in the air. When spoilers are used as speedbrakes their deflection will be symmetrical other than for lateral control when the deflection will be asymmetrical.

key_points: Flaps There are numerous types of flap designs which increase lift and drag in varying amounts
For light aircraft the most popular type is the plain or camber flap
For large transport aircraft the most used is the slotted Fowler flaps
learning.explanation: Flaps There are numerous types of flap designs which increase lift and drag in varying amounts. For light aircraft the most popular type is the plain or camber flap. For large transport aircraft the most used is the slotted Fowler flaps. (see different types in the image in the annex) In the cockpit there will be a selector where the pilot selects the desired flap setting, the input from this selector will be the input for the slat/flap control computers which control, test and monitor the operation of the flaps and slats. This computer’s output will be the input for an electrically controlled hydro-mechanical unit, a hydraulic motor, which drive the transmission which moves the flaps. The position of the flaps is measured with sensors and is indicated in the cockpit. The flaps are protected against asymmetric operation, runaway and over speed. The flap load relief system, or load limiter will retract the flaps to an intermediate position when the airspeed exceeds a predetermined speed. Once the speed has decreased below this speed, the flaps will be automatically returned to the selected flap setting. If the main hydraulic system fails, the emergency operation might be via an alternate hydraulic system or an electric motor which operates the same gear train as the normal operating system.

options.C: By performing a long push on the sidestick priority button.
options.D: By performing a rapid double tap on the sidestick priority button.

key_points: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the fly-by-wire control system
As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once
The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system
learning.explanation: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the fly-by-wire control system. As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once. The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system. This is called dual input. In case that it occurs, an aural warning “DUAL INPUT” and a flashing warning light in sight of each pilot is provided. To allow one pilot to take over controls from the other, which might be necessary in case of incapacitation, etc., a red take-over button is installed on each sidestick that disables the stick on the other side when held. This button works as an autopilot disconnect when pushed once, but when it is pushed and held, it removes the other pilot's inputs from the system, and after 40 seconds of holding (A320 specific) the other pilot is "locked out" from inputs until they push their own prioirty button. When this condition occurs, an aural warning is provided “PRIORITY LEFT/RIGHT”, indicating the active sidestick.

key_points: Slats Slats are aerodynamic surfaces on the leading edge of the wings of fixed-wing aircraft which, when deployed, allow the wing to operate at a higher angle of attack
A higher coefficient of lift is produced as a result of angle of attack and speed, so by deploying slats an aircraft can fly at slower speeds, or take off and land in shorter distances

learning.explanation: Slats Slats are aerodynamic surfaces on the leading edge of the wings of fixed-wing aircraft which, when deployed, allow the wing to operate at a higher angle of attack. A higher coefficient of lift is produced as a result of angle of attack and speed, so by deploying slats an aircraft can fly at slower speeds, or take off and land in shorter distances. They are usually used while landing or performing manoeuvres which take the aircraft close to the stall, but are usually retracted in normal flight to minimize drag. They decrease stall speed. Some aircraft have an autoslat function which will extend the slats automatically if the wing is about to stall. Usually this autoslat function has some conditions before it will function which can be airspeed, flaps and slats settings. When the stall condition ceases the autoslat system will retract the slats.

content.question: When large transport aeroplanes are flying at high speed, full rudder deflection would cause excessive loads on the structure. What system is fitted to the rudder to prevent this happening?

learning.explanation: With a simple control system, full rudder pedal movement will provide full rudder deflection. With high speed aircraft, while it is necessary to have large rudder deflections available at low speed, when flying at high speed, full rudder deflection would cause excessive loads on the structure. To prevent this occurring, a gear change system can be incorporated into the rudder control system. This may be a single gear change which gives a smaller rudder deflection for full pedal movement above a certain speed (Variable Stop), or a progressive gear change which gives a decreasing rudder deflection with full pedal movement as speed increases (Rudder Ratio).

This means that a force applied to the controls is a force which moves the control surface, and also a force which moves the control surface will move the pilot’s controls. This means that the air pressure on the control surface can be felt in the pilot’s controls. When the flight controls are fully power operated this is not the case and is called irreversible. key_points: There are two basic types of flight controls, reversible and irreversible
Reversible flight controls are those that have a two way force mechanism naturally as part of the system

This includes manual flight controls, which use levers and pulleys to transfer pilot force to the controls, and partially powered controls, which are aided by hydraulic force, but there is still a mechanical connection between the pilot and controls (the same as powered steering in a car)
learning.explanation: There are two basic types of flight controls, reversible and irreversible. Reversible flight controls are those that have a two way force mechanism naturally as part of the system. This includes manual flight controls, which use levers and pulleys to transfer pilot force to the controls, and partially powered controls, which are aided by hydraulic force, but there is still a mechanical connection between the pilot and controls (the same as powered steering in a car). The connecting factor means that if you went to the aileron and pushed it, the controls in the cockpit would move accordingly. The opposite are irreversible controls, which have no "backwards force", or "feel". These are only 1 way, so the pilot can move the control surfaces, but the control surfaces cannot move the pilot's controls. Fully powered hydraulic controls and fly-by-wire controls are irreversible. Irreversible controls have no natural feedback, so require artificial "feel", so the pilot has something to push against and the controls naturally centre, etc. If you pushed the aileron, the controls would not move. Therefore, in this scenario, there is no connection at all between the control surfaces and the cockpit controls (especially as the aircraft is powered down, so there is no automatic control centring, etc.). Therefore, if the rudder goes to full deflection by the wind or by someone pushing it, etc., there would be no corresponding movement of the rudder pedals. That would be the case for any irreversible control system, but the rudder pedals would also move if the system were reversible. Therefore, the flight controls on the aircraft described must be fully powered, out of that selection of options.

In case all of the above fail, the system reverts to mechanical backup, where pitch control is achieved through the horizontal stabilizer and lateral control is accomplished using the rudder pedals. The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals. It can limit the controls in such a way that the airframe will not endure G forces out of the limits. Auto-trim will continuously change the "zero point" of the flight control system, and therefore needs no input from the pilot usually, reducing workload. This increases with the square of the velocity, and can become really very large

learning.explanation: Flaps take quite a lot of force in normal operation due to the heavy aerodynamic load they have to withstand. This increases with the square of the velocity, and can become really very large. Flaps are therefore made to be very strong, but as they are only useful in the lower speed range, they are not built to be used at high airspeeds. Each flap setting has a VFE speed, which is the maximum flaps extended speed. Above this speed, the flaps will take too much load, and could be damaged. Modern jet transport aircraft often have a flap load relief system, which detects flap overspeed, and can disengage the flap lock, allowing the airflow to push the flaps to a lower setting, or some intermediate value, so that the flaps do not get damaged. Some systems use hydraulic pressure and physically move the flaps using the standard system, whereas others use the "blowback" system mentioned above.

content.question: Consider the following situation, the rudder ratio limiter of an aircraft gets stuck in high speed/high altitude mode when decelerating for the approach. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: Increased maximum operating speed.
options.B: Reduced crosswind limitation.
options.C: Greater rudder authority during approach.
options.D: A greater flap setting will be required.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.01.05.05: Explain the concept of a rudder deflection limitation (rudder limiter) system and the various means of implementation (rudder ratio changer, variable stops, blow-back). One of the problems with rudders is that they need to be very large and have a large maximum deflection for adequate directional control in the case of an engine failure during take-off or at low speeds, when there is very little airflow, but if this large rudder had a large deflection at the high cruise speeds of a jet aircraft, it could easily break the tail of the aircraft off with the extreme forces. There are a few methods to remove this problem, rudder ratio changers, variable stops, and blow-back. Rudder Ratio Changer: The control commands from the rudder pedals and trim control are modified by a rudder ratio changer. As the aircraft speed increases, the rudder deflection must be reduced proportionately within the range of the rudder pedal depression by the pilot => the rudder pedals move through their full range at all speeds, however, rudder deflection is reduced with increasing airspeed. This rudder ratio changer can be continuous, as described above, or can be a discreet change at a certain airspeed, like changing gears in a car. If this automatic reduction in rudder authority is not applied and rudder is fully deflected when the aircraft is in high speed flight, the huge forces could damage the aircraft, or at least cause violent yaw/roll. Conversely, if the rudder remains in the high-speed, low deflection mode, then there will be insufficient rudder authority to handle engine failures and crosswind landings at low speeds. This means that the approach will have added limitations, such as a higher minimum approach speed and a reduced crosswind limit. The annex above is an extract from the ATR 72 FCOM, an aircraft which does have a discreet rudder ratio changer (called a TLU - Travel Limiting Unit - in the manual) that changes rudder deflection at 180 kts, and the procedure for if a fault occurs. Notice that within the area of the red box, the procedure for if the fault is not resolved (or unsure if resolved) is to increase the VAPP (approach speed) by 10 kt (with associated increased landing distance) and land at an airport with the lowest crosswind, max demonstrated crosswind is 15 kt. To address the other options: The maximum operating speed will not increase, only the minimum. The rudder authority will be less than usual. The flap setting would not need to be greater, as the approach will be faster, so if anything, less flaps may be needed.

key_points: This question is quite shocking to be honest
The examiner is mixing Boeing and Airbus philosophy

learning.explanation: This question is quite shocking to be honest. The examiner is mixing Boeing and Airbus philosophy. Definitely teaching the wrong thing. Press it continuously for 40 secs and it permanently locks the other sidestick out unless the other pilot presses his button. "3) disengage on MCP." CORRECT. I believe they might be referring to the A/P disengage bar which is found on the MCP of Boeing airplanes. If you press this bar down, the A/P disengages. "4) forcefully move the control column." CORRECT. This is known as column or wheel force override and is present in some aircraft, especially small aircraft.

1. When two inputs in a fly by wire system are detected they are not mixed together. The commander's inputs are given the priority electronically

key_points: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the Fly-By-Wire control system
As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once
The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system
learning.explanation: In a Fly-By-Wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the Fly-By-Wire control system. As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once. The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system. This is called dual input. In case that it occurs, an aural warning “DUAL INPUT” and a flashing warning light in sight of each pilot is provided. Even if both controls were deflected fully in the same direction, the sum of the two controls would be no more than the usual full deflection. Otherwise both pilots would have to make an input to get full control deflection, which would be silly. To allow one pilot to take over controls from the other, which might be necessary in case of incapacitation, etc., a red take-over button is installed on each sidestick that disables the stick on the other side. When this condition occurs, an aural warning is provided “PRIORITY LEFT/RIGHT”, indicating the active sidestick.

2. An advantage of a FBW flight control system is the reduced weight of its components in comparison with a conventional flight control system

options.B: Both 1 and 2 are incorrect.

learning.explanation: 021.05.04.01.02: State the advantages of an FBW system in comparison with a conventional flight control system including: weight; pilot workload; flight-envelope protection. Fly-By-Wire (FBW) systems have several advantages over conventional mechanical flight control systems. Wires and electronic connections are significantly lighter than mechanical structural elements. The reduced weight allows for fitting redundant components, most sophisticated systems feature redundant flight control computers and separate computer systems for flight control without making control systems too heavy. Moreover, FBW system computers offer very sophisticated flight-envelope protections. The computers limit the orders to ensure the protection limits are not exceeded. FBW control systems incorporate redundancy on all levels of the control system. Increased number of systems allows safe continuation of flight in case of a system loss.

key_points: Slats Slats are aerodynamic surfaces on the leading edge of the wings of fixed-wing aircraft which, when deployed, allow the wing to operate at a higher angle of attack
A higher coefficient of lift is produced as a result of angle of attack and speed, so by deploying slats an aircraft can fly at slower speeds, or take off and land in shorter distances
They are usually used while landing or performing manoeuvres which take the aircraft close to the stall, but are usually retracted in normal flight to minimize drag
learning.explanation: Slats Slats are aerodynamic surfaces on the leading edge of the wings of fixed-wing aircraft which, when deployed, allow the wing to operate at a higher angle of attack. A higher coefficient of lift is produced as a result of angle of attack and speed, so by deploying slats an aircraft can fly at slower speeds, or take off and land in shorter distances. They are usually used while landing or performing manoeuvres which take the aircraft close to the stall, but are usually retracted in normal flight to minimize drag. They decrease stall speed. Some aircraft have an autoslat function which will extend the slats automatically if the wing is about to stall. Usually this autoslat function has some conditions before it will function which can be airspeed, flaps and slats settings. When the stall condition ceases the autoslat system will retract the slats. With an autoslat system the aircraft has improved stall characteristics as with high angles of attack the stall speed is reduced.

With high speed aircraft, while it is necessary to have large rudder deflections available at low speed, when flying at high speed, full rudder deflection would cause excessive loads on the structure
To prevent this occurring, a gear change system can be incorporated into the rudder control system
learning.explanation: With a simple control system, full rudder pedal movement will provide full rudder deflection. With high speed aircraft, while it is necessary to have large rudder deflections available at low speed, when flying at high speed, full rudder deflection would cause excessive loads on the structure. To prevent this occurring, a gear change system can be incorporated into the rudder control system. This may be a single gear change which gives a smaller rudder deflection for full pedal movement above a certain speed, or a progressive gear change which gives a decreasing rudder deflection with full pedal movement as speed increases.

content.question: The Airbus A320 has Fly By Wire flight controls. Imagine manually flying an Airbus A320 at low altitude and low airspeed, at the critical angle of attack. How can the pilots make the aircraft climb?

options.A: By trimming for a nose-up attitude.
options.B: By engaging AP in vertical speed mode.
options.C: Simply by pulling back on the sidestick.
options.D: By moving the thrust levers forward to increase speed.

key_points: Note: We think that the different authorities have different versions of this question
Some mention that it is a Fly By Wire aircraft, some saying Airbus, and some saying specifically A320
It is the same answer for all these, and EASA are usually talking about A320s when they mention Fly By Wire anyway
learning.explanation: Note: We think that the different authorities have different versions of this question. Some mention that it is a Fly By Wire aircraft, some saying Airbus, and some saying specifically A320. It is the same answer for all these, and EASA are usually talking about A320s when they mention Fly By Wire anyway. We think the questions are similar enough to warrant only this one in the bank, but if further feedback says otherwise, we will add separate questions. Fly By Wire systems A fly by wire control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls. The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals. These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers. These computers provide the input for the servo valves which controls the movement of the hydraulic actuators attached to the flight control surfaces. One of the largest benefits of Fly By Wire is the flight envelope protection system. It has many abilities, including preventing excessive bank angles, preventing the stall, overspeed protection, overload protection, etc. This question used to be very ambiguous, but over the past year it has changed a few times, and now we know it is an Airbus (we believe it says A320 in some exam authorities) and it is flying at the critical angle of attack. As it is at its critical angle of attack, pulling back on the sidestick would make it initially attempt to climb, but as this would further increase the angle of attack and slow the aircraft, the flight envelope protections would step in and stop this pitching backwards. Therefore the only thing that can save us from this scenario is actually adding thrust. This will allow us to increase our speed, decreasing our AoA, and subsequently, the flight controls will allow us to begin a climb. This is the only way to induce any sort of climb from the very low energy state of the question. In fact, the Airbus A320 actually has a set of limiting angles of attack, where different measures will be taken one by one to stop an impending stall. One of those measures is automatically applying TO/GA (Take off/Go around) thrust. You are not expected to know this for the question, so do not assume that the aircraft will automatically do this if you keep pulling back. Video Explanation:

content.question: Rudder trim adjustment in an aeroplane with irreversible flight controls is…

options.A: unnecessary because this aeroplane does not need rudder trim.
options.B: an adjustment of the rudder ratio changer.
options.C: an adjustment of the zero force rudder position.
options.D: an adjustment of the rudder trim tab.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.01.03.05: Explain the operating principle of rudder and aileron trim in a fully powered control system. There are two basic types of flight controls, reversible and irreversible. Reversible flight controls are those that have a two way force mechanism naturally as part of the system. This includes manual flight controls, which use levers and pulleys to transfer pilot force to the controls, and partially powered controls, which are aided by hydraulic force, but there is still a mechanical connection between the pilot and controls (think powered steering in a car). The connecting factor is that if you went to the aileron and pushed it, the controls in the cockpit would move accordingly. The opposite are irreversible controls, which have no "backwards force", or "feel". These are only 1 way, so the pilot can move the control surfaces, but the control surfaces cannot move the pilot's controls. Fully powered hydraulic controls and fly-by-wire controls are irreversible. irreversible controls have no natural feedback, so require artificial "feel", so the pilot has something to push against, the controls naturally centre, etc. If you pushed the aileron, the controls would not move. There are pros and cons to both, but one benefit of irreversible controls such as fly by wire, is that trimming can be made easier. All a simple trim system needs to do is adjust where the system considers the "zero" point to be. Therefore the rudder (in this case) will sit naturally at the new "zero" point, which will produce a constant trim in a particular direction. Pitch trim can differ from this method though, and some manufacturers take their own stance on trimming, such as if the rudder pedals are supposed to move with the trim or not, etc.

options.A: Digital signals are converted into analogue signals by the PCU.
options.B: PCUs are operated by analogue signals.
options.C: Flight controls are connected to control surfaces by direct wire linkages.
options.D: Control wires feed pilot control movements into the PCUs.

key_points: FLY-BY-WIRE SYSTEMS Fly-By-Wire Systems remove the direct linkage from the control wheel to the Power Control Unit (PCU)
A FBW control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls
The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals
learning.explanation: FLY-BY-WIRE SYSTEMS Fly-By-Wire Systems remove the direct linkage from the control wheel to the Power Control Unit (PCU). A FBW control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls. The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals. These control inputs are sent to the Primary Flight Computer (PFC), which converts the mechanical movements of the control surfaces into a comum electrical output. The Actuator Control Electronics (ACE) takes these electrical signals and converts them into analogue signal which are sent to the Power Control Unit (PCU), the hydraulic actuators attached to the flight control surfaces.

If an aircraft has high speed or experiences turbulence, the forces on flight controls can get too high and might cause failure or damage. The relief valve is placed for when that happens, if the pressure gets too high the valve will open allowing the surface to retract. content.question: An aircraft has a fully powered flight control system, linked to a single hydraulic actuator. If this actuator fails, which of the following will happen?

options.A: The control column will become jammed.
options.B: The back-up hydraulic system will be activated.
options.C: The pilot will need to use greater force to manoeuvre the aircraft.
options.D: The control surface will not respond to pilot inputs.

key_points: Fully powered flight controls means that there is no mechanical linkage between the pilot's controls and the control surfaces, but instead, the pilot's control movements command a servo valve which allows hydraulic pressure into the control surface actuators to provide a much larger force to the control surfaces than any pilot would ever be able to produce
There are, however, still some problems with that concept, such as in this question, where redundancy needs to be implemented in case of jammed or broken controls
This is usually done by duplication of actuators, of control runs, hydraulic system backups, multiple control surfaces, etc
learning.explanation: Fully powered flight controls means that there is no mechanical linkage between the pilot's controls and the control surfaces, but instead, the pilot's control movements command a servo valve which allows hydraulic pressure into the control surface actuators to provide a much larger force to the control surfaces than any pilot would ever be able to produce. There are, however, still some problems with that concept, such as in this question, where redundancy needs to be implemented in case of jammed or broken controls. This is usually done by duplication of actuators, of control runs, hydraulic system backups, multiple control surfaces, etc. A hydraulic actuator is a piston in a tube, which is moved by the hydraulic pressure, and mechanically moves the control surface. In this case, the single actuator has failed. If there is no redundancy for this part (which there is not in this scenario), then the control surface will not respond to any of the pilot's movements on the control column. It will be unusable.

options.B: all the way back, and keep it fully back.
options.C: all the way backwards until reaching the stall speed, then use the stick to maintain that attitude only.
options.D: very slowly backwards to avoid stalling.

The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals
These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers
learning.explanation: Fly-By-Wire systems A fly by wire control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls. The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals. These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers. These computers provide the input for the servo valves which controls the movement of the hydraulic actuators attached to the flight control surfaces. One of the largest benefits of fly by wire is the flight envelope protection system. It has many abilities, including preventing excessive bank angles, preventing the stall, overspeed protection, overload protection, etc. In the event of severe windshear, the recommended way to gain altitude and escape the windshear is to apply maximum thrust and pitch up to a high attitude until reaching near the stall speed, then maintain that speed. In theory, a Fly-By-Wire aircraft can actually perform some of that for the pilot. Because of the stall protection of a Fly-By-Wire flight control system, in theory, the pilot can just apply full thrust and pull back on the sidestick all the way, and just hold it there. The aircraft will go into stall protection mode, which in an Airbus A320 (as EASA usually refer to) changes the control logic slightly above αprot then applies TO/GA thrust above αfloor (the pilot should already have applied TO/GA at this point of course), but will not let the aircraft fully stall, no matter how hard the pilot pulls back. Note: this is not the way an Airbus pilot should actually fly a windshear escape manoeuvre, it is simply a theoretical method of doing so. However, the examiner likes to find interesting ways of testing fly-by-wire knowledge, and that includes asking you about the very limits of the systems.

learning.explanation: (Elevator gust lock, Aileron gust lock, Rudder gust lock) Statement 1: There should be suitable design precautions to prevent flight with the gust lock engaged. CORRECT: If an aircraft would take off with a gust lock engaged one or more flight controls would not work. Statement 2: Reversible flight controls should have a gust lock. CORRECT: reversible flight controls will move by external or internal forces and are not held in place by anything, so strong winds could cause damage to the aircraft. A gust lock or control lock, is an internal or external lock and may be fitted to the control surface or the cockpit control. These locks are made for when an aircraft is parked outside with strong or gusty winds these could move the control surfaces against their stops which could cause damage. If these are fitted to the cockpit control they might be made in a way that it is impossible to move the throttle until the control locks are removed. Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude. The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls. The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible. This means that a force applied to the controls is a force which moves the control surface, and also a force which moves the control surface will move the pilot’s controls. This means that the air pressure on the control surface can be felt in the pilot’s controls. When the flight controls are fully power operated this is not the case and is called irreversible. This means that if there is a force moving the control surface this will not move the control columns, and there will be no natural feel on the controls. Because of this there will need to be an artificial feel unit installed in a fully powered or irreversible control system. This artificial feel unit should apply force to the cockpit controls in proportion to the control deflection and in proportion to the aircraft’s speed. This artificial feel system will also work with a trim system, but this works different than a normal trim surface does. A movement of the trimwheel will result in a movement of the electric trim actuator, and so the control surface, but not in the movement of the control column (this is for elevator control). It is different for aileron and rudder trim. Elevator trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim)

key_points: The extension of the left wing flaps generates an uneven increase in lift compared to the lack of flaps on the right wing
Consequently, the left wing raises, inducing a right bank in the aircraft
Furthermore, any aircraft maneuver that involves a turn leads to an elevation in the load factor
learning.explanation: The extension of the left wing flaps generates an uneven increase in lift compared to the lack of flaps on the right wing. Consequently, the left wing raises, inducing a right bank in the aircraft. Furthermore, any aircraft maneuver that involves a turn leads to an elevation in the load factor. Keep in mind that the stall speed grows proportionally to the square root of the load factor. Thus, in this situation, there is a heightened risk of stalling (and entering a spin) if prompt action is not taken, given the diminishing margin to the stall speed. In all cases of asymmetric flap, the wing with the greater amount of flap extended is producing a substantially higher amount of lift. At the same time, increased drag on the flaps-down side creates a pronounced adverse yaw situation, with the nose swinging toward the wing with most flaps deflected.
